summary:
Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder came on as a late substitute in Spurs' 0-0 draw with Burnley, playing only seven minutes. Merson tweeted sarcastically about Townsend's brief appearance.

The conflict began when Merson wrote in his Sky Sports column that "if Andros Townsend can get in (the England team) then it opens it up to anybody." Townsend proved Merson wrong by scoring a stunning equaliser for England against Italy in a friendly match.

Following Townsend's England goal, Merson admitted his mistake and said he was pleased for the player. Townsend had responded on Twitter, highlighting that he had scored despite Merson saying he should be "nowhere near the squad."

Though the dispute appeared to have been resolved after Merson's apology, he couldn't resist taking another jab at Townsend following his limited playing time against Burnley.

Chelsea have made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. If the deal is completed, the Japan international would initially join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. 

Muto, who has 11 caps for Japan and recently graduated with an economics degree from Keio University, has been with FC Tokyo since 2013. He scored 13 goals in his debut season and was named in the J-League's best XI, continuing his strong form this season with three goals in four games.

The club president confirmed Chelsea sent a formal offer with conditions for a summer acquisition, with reports suggesting a £4 million deal. Ogane stated the interest is not connected to Chelsea's £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. If completed, Muto would become the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea. While Muto called the offer "an honour," he has not yet decided whether to accept.

A large-scale Finnish study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The research, published in Pediatrics, examined over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds and found that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by age two. Children who received antibiotics as young babies, especially repeatedly before age two, had higher odds of being overweight, with boys particularly affected. 

The researchers suggest antibiotics may contribute to childhood obesity by killing gut bacteria that normally consume some food, leaving more for the body to absorb, and potentially increasing appetite. They compare this to how antibiotics are used to fatten farm animals. The study highlights concerns about the obesity epidemic, noting that a third of 10-11 year olds and over a fifth of 4-5 year olds in England are overweight or obese. While the study doesn't definitively prove causation, researchers warn about the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy, especially given additional concerns about antibiotic resistance and other health risks like eczema and digestive problems.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, with the incident captured on camera by tourist David Meadwell. The guard lost his footing, knocked his bearskin hat against his sentry box, and dropped his rifle before quickly scrambling to his feet. The embarrassing fall occurred in front of hundreds of tourists on a Thursday afternoon. The 50-year-old tourist from Newcastle-upon-Tyne was filming the ceremony when the incident happened, noting that spectators gasped as the guard went down. The soldier appeared visibly embarrassed after realizing how many people witnessed the fall. The slip is believed to have been caused by metal protectors on the guard's boots. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The passage describes the announcement of a remake of the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which originally drew over 100 million viewers. The remake will air in 2016 and be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History networks. The series tells the story of Kunta Kinte, an African who was captured, shipped to America, and sold into slavery on a Virginia plantation. 

LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new version. The remake is described as "original" and "contemporary," drawing more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family," with consultation from scholars in African and African-American history for authenticity.

Executive producer Mark Wolper, son of the original producer David L. Wolper, and History's Dirk Hoogstra expressed pride in bringing the story to both fans of the original and new audiences. The remake comes at a time when America has seen its first African-American president, the success of "12 Years a Slave," but also racial unrest over police treatment of black suspects. Burton noted that many young Americans don't know the story of "Roots" or its importance.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has made allegations that palace aides attempted to force him into an orgy at Clarence House in January 1978, when he was 27 years old. Lawler claims that on his first day of work, he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member after entering a bedroom to look for a pen. According to his account, four men were involved in the incident, including a senior staff member. The traumatic experience caused him to leave the job the same day.

Lawler, now 64 and a former Port of Liverpool police officer, reported making a complaint at the time but says it drew an angry response from Clarence House. He contacted palace officials again last year following inquiries into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring in the 1970s and 80s. However, he claims his complaints were ignored for months before police were finally notified.

The police are now investigating the claims. A retired royal aide in his 80s was reportedly interviewed but denied involvement, stating he was working for the Queen in Balmoral at the time. The Palace has stated they would work "exhaustively and co-operatively" with any police probe, while police have said it would be inappropriate to comment as investigations continue.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" theme song that has garnered over 1.7 million YouTube views. In the parody, filmed in their car, the couple raps about living in Happy Valley, Oregon, buying their first house, and facing questions from family about having children. They reveal it took only two months to conceive, though they expected it would take longer. The video culminates with Melissa rapping about discovering she was pregnant after taking a test and seeing "the little plus sign," followed by the couple sharing a sonogram image. The video required five takes to film and was originally created to inform distant relatives about the pregnancy. The couple expressed surprise at the video's viral success and mentioned they might create another video after learning the baby's gender. Jesse Meek is noted as the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek. This follows a similar pregnancy announcement made by a Pennsylvania couple using the same theme song the previous year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills, California on Saturday. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, which originally was slate blue-gray but has faded over time, was worn in key scenes including when Scarlett encounters Rhett Butler (Clark Gable) and during the shanty town attack. 

The dress was part of a collection of over 150 Gone With the Wind items owned by James Tumblin, former head of Universal Studios' hair and makeup department. Tumblin rescued the dress from being thrown away at Western Costume Company in the 1960s, purchasing it for $20. He amassed over 300,000 pieces of Hollywood memorabilia throughout his collecting career.

Other notable items sold included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), Clark Gable's Rhett Butler suit ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000). The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary last year and notably featured Hattie McDaniel as Mammy, who became the first African-American to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell 10-12 feet into a cheetah exhibit at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo on Saturday around 3pm after his parents dangled him over the edge. The mother was holding him and another child when he slipped. The parents rescued the boy from the pit before emergency responders arrived. The child suffered minor bumps and bruises, including a leg injury, but was not attacked by the cheetahs and is in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. Witnesses reported seeing the child dangled over the railing, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or parents, likely because they were frightened by the screaming crowd. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

A decommissioned speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham has been mysteriously turned to point directly at a house's front door instead of the road. The yellow gatso camera, which previously enforced a 30mph speed limit on the residential road, has been non-functional for over two years since all fixed speed cameras in the West Midlands were switched off in March 2013 due to obsolete technology. 

Currently, speed enforcement in the region is handled by mobile camera units, motorway cameras, and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council is aware of the repositioned camera and will send an engineer to investigate, with the possibility of removing it entirely. The council is developing a pilot program for new digital cameras at limited sites, but the Wellington Road camera will not be included. The homeowners were unavailable for comment, and it remains unknown who repositioned the camera.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2-3. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association announced his participation, with Bolt stating he is "fit, healthy and ready to run." He expressed enthusiasm about the event, noting it had a great atmosphere the previous year and emphasizing Jamaica's strong relay tradition. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure at Bolt's availability for selection. The full Jamaican team roster will be announced at a later date.

Barcelona football players Neymar and Dani Alves attended a Euro League basketball match between Barcelona and Real Madrid on Thursday night, accompanied by Neymar's sister Rafaella. Barcelona won the basketball game 85-80, though Real Madrid remains top of their Euro League division on points difference. Prior to this, Neymar had captained Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile at the Emirates Stadium on Sunday in a physical match. In football, Barcelona had recently won their El Clasico match and moved four points clear at the top of La Liga. The team was set to face Celta Vigo on Sunday as they pursue a treble of trophies.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. From Friday to Monday, Italian coast guards rescued 8,480 migrants, with 20 distress calls received on Monday alone. Save the Children reported that 400 migrants may be missing after a boat carrying 550 people allegedly capsized 80 miles off Libya's coast, though the Italian coast guard could not confirm this incident despite search efforts. 

In the first three months of 2015, over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy, with 2,000 rescued during the first weekend of April in the Channel of Sicily. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean since the year's beginning, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels operated by smugglers who sometimes abandon their passengers.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger discusses Alexis Sanchez's decision to join Arsenal over Liverpool last summer. The Chile forward, who cost £32 million from Barcelona, had multiple elite clubs interested but chose Arsenal, though Wenger admits he doesn't know the exact reason why. Wenger acknowledges Liverpool's interest may have been used as leverage during negotiations for Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Sanchez has made an immediate impact at Arsenal, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger praises Sanchez's qualities including efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit, noting his ability to revitalize the team. Looking ahead to Arsenal's match against Liverpool, Wenger downplays speculation about a potential move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and commends Brendan Rodgers for adapting well after losing Suarez and dealing with Daniel Sturridge's injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, the four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The 35-year-old (turning 35 on April 28) will try to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes at the Lee Valley VeloPark.

Wiggins called the Hour Record "a holy grail for cyclists" that has been contested by great names in the sport for over a hundred years. He recently finished his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix and will ride in the Tour de Yorkshire before preparing for this attempt.

The current hour record stands at 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Previous recent attempts include Jens Voigt (51.115km), Matthias Brandle (51.852km), and an unsuccessful attempt by Jack Bobridge. British rider Alex Dowsett will attempt to break the record on May 2 in Manchester.

Wiggins aims to race in front of a capacity 6,000 crowd, with tickets going on sale April 19 (priced £49, £39, and £29). The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. This attempt is part of Wiggins' return to track cycling as he targets a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics in the team pursuit.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Serena Williams defeated Sara Errani 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3 in a Fed Cup singles match on Sunday, extending her career record against Errani to 8-0. Despite the win, Williams called the difficult match an "eye-opener," revealing she was not as prepared for the clay court season as she thought. The US ultimately lost the Fed Cup tie 3-2 to Italy, with Williams and Alison Riske losing the doubles match 6-0, 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta. This defeat relegated the US to World Group II. Williams, who won her 19th Grand Slam at the Australian Open, acknowledged she needs to adjust her playing style for clay courts. The doubles loss marked Williams' first Fed Cup defeat, and US captain Mary Joe Fernandez expressed hope that the team could win their way back to the World Group next year.

River Plate are interested in re-signing striker Radamel Falcao, who is currently on loan at Manchester United from Monaco. Falcao previously played for the Argentine club for eight years before leaving for Porto in 2009, having joined River Plate at age 15 in 2001 and making his first-team debut in 2005. During his time there, he scored 34 goals in 90 appearances.

The 29-year-old Colombian has struggled at Manchester United this season, scoring only four Premier League goals. River Plate's vice president Matias Patanian expressed the club's interest, stating "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open," though he acknowledged that any potential deal would be complicated.

Despite his difficulties at United, Falcao has been in good form for Colombia recently, scoring three goals in two games to equal his country's all-time goalscoring record of 24 goals. It remains uncertain whether Manchester United will exercise their option to sign him permanently or if he will return to Monaco.

X Factor finalist Ella Henderson, 19, has been announced as the face of Batiste dry shampoo's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features the pop star in glamorous images against blurred city backgrounds, showcasing various hairstyles including wavy locks and a tousled half-ponytail. She appears wearing outfits including a black blouse with fringed leather jacket and a black animal-print sheer panel dress. The partnership, arranged by MILES agency, launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's single "Mirror Man." Her manager Mark Hargreaves noted this as Henderson's first endorsement deal, highlighting the natural synergy between the platinum award-winning artist and the UK's number 1 dry shampoo brand.

A 26-year-old man named Aaron Siler was fatally shot by police officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin on March 14 after Siler "armed himself with a weapon" during a confrontation. Torres is currently on leave while the shooting is investigated.

Following the incident, the Kenosha Professional Police Association erected a billboard featuring Torres and his dog with the message "Thank you for your support, Kenosha." This billboard has upset Siler's family and friends, who consider it disrespectful. Family friend Kathy Willie interpreted it as "thank you for killing Aaron" and reported that Siler's mother cried upon hearing about it.

The police association claims the billboard was meant to thank the community for their support during recent difficult incidents. Siler was wanted on a felony probation and parole warrant and was shot following a vehicle and foot pursuit.

This was Torres's second shooting in 10 days - he had previously shot 66-year-old Terry Knight on March 4, who was armed with knives during a suicide call. That shooting was ruled justified. The state Division of Criminal Investigation is investigating both shootings, with Siler's case still ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border in the southeastern town of Negur on Monday. Three militants were killed by Iranian forces during the fighting. According to Iranian officials, the militants crossed into Iran from Pakistan.

The militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack. This Sunni Muslim anti-Iranian group has emerged in recent years in Pakistan's Balochistan province, targeting Shiites and aiming to counter Iranian influence in Pakistan. The group has claimed previous attacks on Iranian territory, including one in October 2013 that killed 14 Iranian border guards.

Iran has criticized Pakistan for failing to control these terrorists, who allegedly flee back into Balochistan after attacks. Pakistan condemned the attack as terrorism and stated its security agencies are investigating the incident. The Pakistani government has requested evidence from Iran and pledged to apprehend any militants who entered Pakistan after the attack.

The passage describes a political discussion in Japan's parliament about UFOs and potential extraterrestrial encounters. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani responded to a question from Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler-turned-lawmaker, confirming that Japan's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered any UFOs from outer space. While the ASDF does scramble fighter jets to investigate unidentified flying objects that might violate Japanese airspace, Nakatani stated they only find birds or other earthly objects, never anything believed to be extraterrestrial.

The passage provides background on Inoki, describing him as a colorful political figure who founded New Japan Pro Wrestling, appeared in WWE, fought Muhammad Ali in 1976, and has been involved in various diplomatic efforts including trips to Iraq and North Korea. Known for his distinctive chin and red scarf/necktie, Inoki claims to have personally seen a UFO but admits uncertainty about alien existence.

The article notes this isn't the first time Japanese politicians have discussed extraterrestrial matters, referencing a 2007 incident when then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considered the legal implications of defending against an alien invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger named Jin Pai was hospitalized with deep cuts to his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China's Anhui Province. The incident occurred when Jin Pai was standing on the toilet rim because he was worried the seat might not be clean. The porcelain toilet tipped over and shattered, severely cutting him in multiple places. Too embarrassed to call for help, he contacted his traveling companions but required immediate hospitalization, where he received dozens of stitches on his left leg and buttocks. While Jin Pai initially admitted to friends that he was squatting on the toilet, he later told police he was sitting when it broke, possibly to avoid paying compensation. Authorities deemed it an accident, with police reminding people that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom. Rebbie faces multiple charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy.

The investigation began in March when the victim found the camera under her bathroom sink. She reported that Rebbie had been watching her for years while she undressed and when she was asleep. The girl also disclosed that Rebbie molested her in her bedroom from ages 9 to 13.

Police found 41 videos from the hidden camera showing the girl and others using the bathroom, with 34 videos of victims showering. The footage, captured over 3-4 years, included close-up images of children's genitalia. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple victims, including juveniles, but specifically purchased the camera to record the 15-year-old victim.

Rebbie uploaded the videos to his computer for later viewing. His preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is being held on $500,000 bail. The relationship between Rebbie and the victim's family remains unknown.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a unique series of father-daughter portraits where daughters stand still and smile at the camera while their fathers leap dramatically into the air beside them. The 37-year-old photographer's images are part of a book that roughly translates to "Daughter and Salary Man." 

According to the photographer's website, the concept allows fathers who typically must act serious to express their fun side by being "a hero jumping the sky." Each photo shows the daughter in casual clothing while the father wears a sharp business suit. The portraits are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks.

The images capture fathers of various ages making energetic jumps, with some older fathers showing slightly pained expressions during their leaps. While the daughters remain po-faced in most shots, one young girl is shown giggling at her father's ambitious jump. The unusual portrait series has generated significant online interest, though little else is known about why the photos were created.

The passage covers Kevin Pietersen's participation in Surrey's team photo shoot at the KIA Oval ahead of the new County Championship season. The main points include:

- Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has opened the possibility for Pietersen's return to the England team
- Pietersen displayed mixed emotions during the photo shoot - appearing in deep thought at times while also being jovial and joking with photographers and teammates
- He sat at the end of the front row in the team photo
- Pietersen was controversially dropped from England by Downton in 2014, last playing internationally during England's whitewash Ashes defeat in Australia
- He has rejoined Surrey to try to force his way back into England's Test team, with England hoping to regain the Ashes at home this summer
- Surrey's Championship campaign begins at Glamorgan on April 19, with a warm-up match against Oxford MCCU on Sunday

The passage suggests Pietersen's potential England return has taken "a step closer" following Downton's departure.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, who are struggling with relegation, fired Brazilian coach Ze Maria twice within a week. The 41-year-old former Brazil defender (25 caps) was initially sacked on Wednesday due to poor results, but owner Angelo Massone reinstated him the next day. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani on Saturday that left the team 16th in the standings and six points from safety, Ze Maria was fired again. Ze Maria, who had replaced Florin Marin in January as the club's third coach of the season, will be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Based on the passage, here is a concise summary:

Radamel Falcao moved from Monaco to Manchester United on a season-long loan last summer. His former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao now regrets this move. At United, Falcao has struggled to perform at his previous level following a serious knee injury, scoring only four goals all season. While United has an option to make the transfer permanent for £46 million, they are unlikely to exercise it due to his poor form. According to Dirar, although Falcao was unhappy at Monaco, he would have been better off staying there where he would have had more playing time and Champions League participation.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday, stealing approximately $1,500 in cash and the till. The robbery occurred at the Union St dairy in east Christchurch around 12:30pm. The offender, described as very tall, demanded cash from the owner's daughter, causing her to run from the shop screaming. He threw the cash register to the ground and fled with the till drawer. While no weapons were reportedly used, the robber remains at large. Police have released security footage and are appealing to the public for help identifying the masked man, asking anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with underage students. She was first arrested on March 19 after admitting to kissing a 15-year-old student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. Following this arrest, she was suspended and placed on administrative leave.

Granado was arrested again on Monday after a second 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights (January 18 and 19) across from another Dallas school. The second victim came forward after police learned of rumors about another possible relationship. She was released on $50,000 bail after her second arrest. The school district has banned her from working with students or being present on any district property.

A large crocodile was filmed swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, carrying a dead pet dog in its jaws. The video, which has been viewed over 500,000 times online, shows the crocodile calmly gliding through the water with a black dog wearing a red collar. 

New Zealand tourist Tim Weston, who witnessed the incident while on holiday with his wife, reported that the dog belonged to a local bike shop owner. According to Weston, the dog had approached the water's edge out of curiosity when it was attacked. The crocodile held the dog in its mouth for hours without moving.

The incident occurred near a crocodile sanctuary located 200 meters up the river from the marina. Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta, as the resort is built among mangroves that have been their natural habitat for centuries. American Crocodiles in Mexico can grow up to 6 meters in length and are living increasingly close to humans due to urbanization.

The video sparked strong reactions on social media, with viewers expressing horror and disgust at the footage.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Hull City manager Steve Bruce remains confident he can keep the club in the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton that left them just two points above the relegation zone. Hull lost to goals from James Ward-Prowse (penalty) and Graziano Pelle, despite playing well in the first half. 

Bruce originally targeted 10 wins for survival but Hull have managed only six so far. They face a difficult run-in with six games remaining, including fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic and Robert Snodgrass.

Southampton moved up to fifth place with the victory. Manager Ronald Koeman had to deal with an incident where Sadio Mane tried to take the penalty instead of designated taker Ward-Prowse, and plans to address this breach of team rules with his squad.

A teacher named Ian Guffick has been banned from teaching for at least two years after allowing pupils to change their SATs exam answers at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire. The 31-year-old asked pupils to make changes to their national curriculum tests after the exam session had finished, and also altered some pupils' answers himself before the papers were sent off. 

Following a tip-off in June, an investigation by the local education authority confirmed the breach of exam rules. As a result, the Department for Education annulled all SATs results for the entire school for 2014. Guffick was forced to resign from his position and admitted to unacceptable professional conduct, though he claimed he only asked pupils to make their answers more legible.

A conduct panel found that while his actions were dishonest, they fell short of fraud. The panel acknowledged Guffick showed remorse and was forthcoming during the investigation. Education Secretary Nicky Morgan's representative imposed the teaching ban, noting the serious impact on the school and that Guffick's actions were deliberate. Guffick has 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard enjoyed time off with his wife Misse Beqiri, a Swedish model with Albanian roots. The couple married last year in a beach wedding in Mauritius and have been dating since 2012, with a son together. Lindegaard, a 31-year-old Danish international, has struggled for playing time at Manchester United since joining from Norwegian side Aalesunds in 2010, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons. He is currently third-choice goalkeeper behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Despite being told he can leave United and a failed January move to FC Midtjylland, Lindegaard shared his happiness off the pitch by posting on Instagram about spending time with his wife in Cheshire/Manchester. Beqiri, who has over 17,000 Instagram followers, regularly posts modeling photos on social media.

The 13 glowing blue letters that spelled "YANKEE STADIUM" and hung above the stadium from 1976 to 2008 failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction on Wednesday. Despite being estimated to fetch $300,000 to $600,000, the letters received no legitimate bids, with only a Sotheby's employee bidding $260,000 to try to start the bidding process. The current owner is Yankees Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased the 10-feet-tall letters after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson, who attended the auction, had hoped a new generation would own the iconic signage and had promised to visit the letters if they were sold to a U.S. buyer. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s, estimated at only $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed incidents involving players Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe, who were photographed with shisha pipes and Sterling was also exposed for inhaling nitrous oxide. Rodgers spoke to both players in his office but will not discipline them, instead reminding them of their professional responsibilities as elite athletes. 

Sterling will lead Liverpool's attack at Wembley in their FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa due to Daniel Sturridge's injury. Captain Steven Gerrard is available after serving a three-match suspension, though Rodgers hasn't confirmed if he'll start.

Rodgers emphasized that reaching this semi-final is part of Liverpool's journey, noting that winners often experience losses before achieving success. He aims to guide Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his management, having previously fallen short in the title race and Capital One Cup semi-final.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil posted a picture on Twitter relaxing at home with his dog after returning from international duty, where he helped Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier on Sunday. The £42.5million signing from Real Madrid missed Arsenal's last game against Newcastle due to illness, but is expected to play against Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium this weekend. Despite rumors of being spotted in a Berlin nightclub, manager Arsene Wenger dismissed these claims. Ozil has been in excellent form since returning from injury in January, contributing four assists and three goals. The German playmaker says he has adapted well to English football, appreciating the frequent matches despite the demanding schedule with no winter break.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club has no intention of replacing manager Luis Enrique and is "very happy" with his performance. Enrique, 44, joined Barcelona last summer on a two-year contract and is currently just six games away from winning La Liga. Despite speculation about his potential replacement, Bartomeu dismissed these claims, praising Enrique's work ethic and noting that Barcelona is among the few clubs still competing for three trophies this late in the season. Enrique's contract runs until 2016. The team recently defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, demonstrating their strong form under his leadership.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract with Liverpool following their FA Cup disappointment. The 24-year-old vice-captain, who had 14 months left on his existing deal, will sign improved terms worth around £100,000 per week running until 2020. Henderson becomes the third key player to extend his contract under Brendan Rodgers, after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. The England midfielder, signed from Sunderland for £16million in 2011, has excelled this season with 13 assists and seven goals, and is being considered as Steven Gerrard's replacement as club captain when Gerrard moves to LA Galaxy. Meanwhile, contract talks with Raheem Sterling are expected to resume at the end of the season.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Filipe Luis, who joined Chelsea from Atletico Madrid in July on a three-year contract, has stated he wants to remain at Chelsea until his contract ends, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. The left back has struggled to secure a regular starting position at Chelsea. Luis recently played for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile during the international break. With nine difficult Premier League matches remaining, Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is keeping the league-leading team focused on winning every game to secure the title, with Luis acknowledging the challenging run-in ahead.

Nathan Hughes, a Wasps No 8 player, had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after being initially suspended for accidentally knocking out George North during a match on March 27. Hughes's knee collided with the Welsh winger's head as North scored a try for Northampton, resulting in Hughes receiving a red card. This was North's third head injury in two months, leading to him being advised to take at least a month off.

The original disciplinary panel deemed Hughes "reckless" despite accepting there was no intent. However, following widespread criticism of the ban from players and observers - including James Haskell, Andy Goode, Austin Healey, and Joe Marler who called it a "joke" - Wasps successfully appealed. The appeal panel, with access to new evidence, concluded that no foul play occurred and the incident was accidental, officially rescinding both the red card and suspension. Hughes is now free to play immediately.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Dramatic reddish sunsets appeared in Washington and other parts of the Pacific Northwest over the weekend, photographed by Seattle native Tim Durkan. The unusual amber-colored haze was caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia that started when farmers' controlled grass burning spread out of control due to strong winds on April 14. The fires destroyed dozens of villages before being extinguished. Atmospheric winds carried the smoke across the Pacific Ocean to Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red color occurs because smoke particles filter out shorter wavelength colors (greens, blues, yellows, purples), allowing only reds and oranges to penetrate. The effect is most dramatic during sunrises and sunsets when light travels through more atmosphere. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the fiery sunsets will fade.

A Missouri mother, Becky Schoenig from St. Louis, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway on Monday night, just over a month after purchasing it. On April 1st, police recovered the vehicle after receiving a tip from a man named Mick Sexton who recognized it as Schoenig's car. When the car was returned, it had been modified with red spray-painted rims, red detailing on the sides, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Rather than being upset, Schoenig humorously embraced the changes, posting on Facebook: "I want to thank the car thieves for pimping out my vehicle for me.... This b***h is pimpin now!!!" Despite her positive attitude, she is having the car professionally cleaned due to the strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana. To honor Mick Sexton for helping recover her car, Schoenig is creating a smoothie called "The Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, featuring banana, pineapple, peach and coconut cream.

Manchester City players face losing £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. Star players including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart and Yaya Toure are on incentivised contracts designed to help the club meet financial fairplay requirements. 

Following their derby defeat to Manchester United, City sit in fourth place with their European qualification hopes uncertain. They are just four points ahead of Liverpool, who have a game in hand. The top three Premier League teams qualify automatically for the Champions League, while fourth place must win a qualifying round.

The entire City squad has approximately £12 million in bonuses dependent on reaching their European target. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team has "thrown it into the garbage" over the last three months of 2015, having started the year level with Chelsea but subsequently losing seven times and exiting both the FA Cup and Champions League early.

This situation could also impact City's ability to sign world-class players like Paul Pogba, who is also a target for Manchester United.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a youth derby match played at Altrincham's Moss Lane stadium. The match featured predominantly English players (13 of 22 starters), with 10 being from Manchester. 

Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick just before the hour mark, after drawing a foul with skillful footwork. The match was free to attend and drew nearly 1,000 spectators. United played with three defenders and wingbacks, mirroring their senior team's formation.

Notable performances included Marcus Wood's near-miss for City and Marcus Rashford's missed chances for United. Cameron Borthwick-Jackson hit the crossbar for United, while City's late attempts through Aaron Nemane and Javairo Dilrosun failed to find an equalizer.

The victory leaves United two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City have lost both matches in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League play-off series. The match showcased promising young talent from both Manchester clubs.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart earned his 50th international cap in a 1-1 draw against Italy on Tuesday night. Hart praised Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon, who won his 147th cap in the same match, calling him a "legend of the game" and an inspiration. The 27-year-old Manchester City goalkeeper, who is 10 years younger than the 37-year-old Buffon, expressed that he is still learning from watching how Buffon operates. Hart stated his pride in reaching 50 caps and his determination to continue representing England, saying he wants to "keep playing well for my club and country and rack them up."

Chipotle has partnered with the Postmates app to enter the $70 billion food delivery market, offering delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. The service will include a 9% service charge plus Postmates delivery fees starting at $5, varying by distance and demand. This marks a shift for Chipotle, which had previously rejected third-party delivery partnerships. The move follows similar delivery initiatives by other major chains including Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King. The restaurant chain has recently gained attention from presidential candidates, with both Marco Rubio (a regular customer) and Hillary Clinton being spotted at Chipotle locations.

The parents of 8-year-old Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have published an opinion piece in The Boston Globe urging authorities to drop the death penalty for convicted bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.

Bill and Denise Richard, whose daughter Jane was also severely injured in the attack, argue that life in prison without possibility of release would be preferable to the death penalty. They explain that capital punishment would lead to years of appeals, prolonging their family's suffering and forcing their surviving children to relive the trauma.

Tsarnaev was found guilty on all 30 charges related to the 2013 bombings that killed three people and wounded over 200. The sentencing phase begins Tuesday and is expected to last four weeks. His brother Tamerlan was killed in a police shootout two years ago.

The Richards acknowledge the "heinousness and brutality" of the crimes, noting they witnessed graphic evidence during the trial including video, photographs, and their son's clothing from his last day. However, they believe accepting life imprisonment would allow their family and Boston to "turn the page, end the anguish, and look toward a better future."

The passage describes a custom-built Boeing 747 that has been converted into a luxury private home for a mystery billionaire. The aircraft, which normally carries up to 600 passengers, was customized over three years at a cost of £400 million to serve just one owner and their guests.

Key features of the converted jumbo jet include:
- Multiple bedrooms, including a master bedroom with a large bed, armchair and sofa
- Several lounges with hotel-like décor
- A dining room with an adjoining kitchen for private chef services
- A conference room with a long table for business meetings
- An "aeroloft" on the top deck containing eight full beds
- A "state room" at the back of the plane
- Office space that can double as a guest bedroom

The interior design completely abandons traditional airplane seating rows in favor of a luxury hotel ambience, making it one of the most luxurious private planes ever built. Artist's impressions by Greenpoint Technologies show spaces that could easily be mistaken for high-end hotel rooms rather than the inside of an aircraft.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket on Tuesday from Cape Canaveral, Florida, carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station. While the launch was successful, SpaceX's attempt to land the rocket's first stage on a floating barge failed - the rocket landed but tipped over due to landing too hard. This was their second attempt at barge landing after a January failure.

The Dragon spacecraft is delivering over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the ISS, including research equipment and an espresso maker. After about five weeks, the crew will load Dragon with over 3,000 pounds of experiments and other materials to return to Earth, where it will splashdown in the Pacific Ocean off California.

This marks SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS, with the company being the first private contractor to dock with the station. The launch was delayed one day due to weather. SpaceX aims to master rocket landing and reuse to reduce space access costs by up to 100 times, according to founder Elon Musk.

Priscilla Presley, 69, will witness the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel at the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas on April 23. She collaborated with NBC's Today show to create a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the "ultimate wedding." The winning couple, to be announced next Monday, will receive a free wedding reception, two-night hotel suite, airfares, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. The Westgate Hotel, formerly the Las Vegas Hilton, is where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows. Priscilla, who married Elvis in 1967, emphasized that the chapel is "first-class" and will not feature impersonators. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis's artifacts outside his Memphis home. Couples must submit videos or photos explaining why they deserve to win the contest.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League race for Champions League qualification, despite being four points behind. In Liverpool's 2-0 win over Newcastle United on Monday night, both Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season, equalling the record for appearances by any player in Europe's top five leagues this campaign. 

The victory came after disappointing results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring in the ninth minute, and Joe Allen sealed the win with his first Anfield goal with 20 minutes remaining. Newcastle had a strong penalty appeal when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Perez, which even Allen admitted looked valid. The win helps Liverpool maintain pressure on Manchester City, who have been faltering recently, including a 4-2 loss to Manchester United.

Roma broke their four-month home winless streak by defeating Napoli 1-0 in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored the only goal in the 25th minute following a swift counter-attack. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis was instrumental in preserving the victory, making multiple saves in the second half against Napoli's attacks.

The win moved second-place Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, ending a seven-match winless run at home since November 30. Meanwhile, Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches, leaving them in fifth place.

The match featured tight security due to tensions from a previous incident where a Napoli fan died before last season's Italian Cup final. Residents from the Campania region were banned from purchasing tickets, and 1,000 police officers were deployed, though no problems were reported.

Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and Gervinho, while Napoli's Lorenzo Insigne made his return from a knee injury sustained in November.

Doncaster Rovers, experiencing a disappointing season in mid-table of League One, played out a goalless draw against Fleetwood Town at the Keepmoat Stadium on Saturday. Fleetwood, whose play-off hopes had faded, were equally uninspired in what proved to be an uneventful match. The game was so devoid of highlights that Doncaster's media team created a 27-second highlights video for YouTube, containing just 14 seconds of actual match footage - showing only the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Roland Giroux has developed a remarkable relationship with his blood parrot cichlid fish, which he demonstrates by hand-feeding and physically petting it. In videos uploaded to his YouTube channel, Giroux places his hand in the tank and gently cups the fish, which then relaxes and remains still while being stroked with his finger. Though the fish occasionally swims away, it repeatedly returns to rest in Giroux's hand for more massage. The fish also interacts by swimming up his arm and circling his fingers.

This relationship developed after Giroux removed two other fish that were bullying his blood parrot cichlid. He began hand-feeding it frozen blood worms, and the fish gradually became more sociable, eventually enjoying being stroked. Giroux now plays with and massages his fish for at least 15 minutes daily, noting that the fish becomes frustrated without this daily interaction. When he removes his hand from the tank, the fish follows it to the surface, appearing saddened.

The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan around 1986, created from midas and redhead cichlids.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' return to the England cricket team at the Kensington Oval, where he had previously broken his wrist punching a locker after being dismissed. The author describes Stokes as a fiery character who brings excitement to cricket at a time when the game risks producing "robots." 

Key points covered include:
- Stokes' confrontational style, including facing Mitchell Johnson during the Ashes and clashing with Marlon Samuels in the second Test
- Coach Peter Moores' intervention after the Samuels incident, providing guidance on how to respond appropriately
- The need for careful management of Stokes to channel his aggression productively without crushing his natural exuberance
- The importance of Stokes producing runs and wickets alongside his aggressive personality
- England's desire to play both Stokes and Chris Jordan regularly to help them develop in international cricket
- A minor back injury that might affect Stokes' participation in Barbados

The author emphasizes that while Stokes' character is valuable to the team, his aggression must be controlled and natural rather than forced to live up to his reputation.

The passage describes Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium, which has sold out all 33,000 tickets. Both teams have 11 points from five games in Group B, with Belgium (ranked fourth in the world) leading on goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel, featuring a Gareth Bale free-kick, has increased expectations that they could qualify for their first major tournament since the 1958 World Cup. The Football Association of Wales reported overwhelming demand for tickets following the Israel win. Despite speculation about moving to the larger Millennium Stadium (74,500 capacity), UEFA rules prevent venue changes within 120 days of the match, and the Wales squad reportedly prefers the more intimate Cardiff City Stadium where they haven't played since 2011.

England's Under-17 coach John Peacock has announced his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria next month. England are the defending champions, having defeated Holland on penalties in last year's final, and qualified for this tournament with a perfect record. 

The Young Lions have been drawn in Group D alongside Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their tournament begins on May 7 against Italy in Burgas, followed by matches against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

The 18-player squad includes players from several Premier League clubs, with notable selections including Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock (receiving his first call-up) and Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold (both returning after missing the Elite Round qualifiers). England reached the finals by defeating Romania, Norway, and Slovenia in the Elite Round qualifiers last month.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best talents from Anderlecht's youth system. Arsenal and Barcelona have also shown interest in the Belgian teenager. When he was 12, Patoulidis rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy because his family wanted him to continue his studies. City have held discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to try to agree a compensation package for the player.

A 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan was found dead in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March. She died from injuries to her head and neck, having been strangled and beaten. 

A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed pending further questioning. 

According to her website, Santillan worked as an escort in London, Paris and Miami, and had described herself as visiting London from Miami. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death to come forward. 

London Ambulance Service was called to the scene on March 28 at around 9:30pm, where she was pronounced dead. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation and seeking information about why this happened.

Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show after discovering that £207 saved for her baby's gravestone had been stolen. The money was part of £500 needed for a headstone for her son Daniel James, the only one of her miscarried babies she had to bury. 

Dawn accused her housemate Jamie, a convicted burglar who lives with her and her partner (also named Jamie), of taking the money. Initially, Jamie and his girlfriend Carol denied the theft. However, a lie detector test on the show revealed Jamie had indeed stolen the cash. Jamie had also sent Dawn a Facebook message during their journey to London, confessing to taking the money but blaming Carol.

Upon learning the truth, Dawn burst into tears and left the stage, later expressing feelings of betrayal and devastation that someone she had tried to help had stolen money meant for her baby's memorial.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis on Wednesday, mostly women, children, elderly, and ill individuals, according to officials. The release was coordinated with help from Arab tribal leaders, though the specific motivation remains unclear. The freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil, the Kurdish regional capital.

This release follows ISIS's brutal campaign against the Yazidi minority that began in summer 2014, when the terror group overtook northern Iraqi towns, forcing hundreds of thousands from their homes. The Yazidis, a Kurdish religious minority that predates Islam, faced extraordinary persecution from ISIS, including mass killings and the enslavement of women.

The ISIS conquest of Sinjar created a major humanitarian crisis, with many Yazidis trapped in mountains without food or water. This prompted international intervention, including airdrops of supplies, rescue operations, and U.S.-led coalition airstrikes against ISIS starting in August 2014.

The Yazidi population in northern Iraq is estimated at 500,000, representing less than 1% of Iraq's total population. ISIS had previously released other groups of Yazidis, mainly children and elderly, since their initial attacks.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham striker who has had a breakthrough season, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. The young striker has scored 20 Premier League goals this season and has also broken into Roy Hodgson's England team, scoring on his debut. Copa90 has created an animated video featuring Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, including strikes against Chelsea and Arsenal. The video uses still photographs layered to create an animation effect and is titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?" Kane is competing against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize at the upcoming Sunday awards ceremony.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers should remain as Liverpool manager despite a third consecutive trophyless season and likely missing out on top-four qualification. Liverpool are seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City with a game in hand. Carragher stated that a manager's future shouldn't be determined by one game and that Rodgers needs to identify areas for improvement and make the right signings for next season. 

Carragher received a Beacon Award in London for his community work on Merseyside through his 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in eight schools in deprived areas. The former Liverpool defender, who played 737 games for the club, aims to help youngsters from under-privileged areas like his hometown of Bootle realize their goals.

A four-year-old boy named James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport security while traveling with his parents to Lanzarote. The toy, which fires sponge darts and was packed in hand luggage, was detected by X-ray machines and deemed a security risk. Security officers not only confiscated the £6 toy but also performed a pat-down search on the child. James's father, Phil Hayward, criticized the security measures as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous." The family had to leave the toy behind to avoid missing their flight. East Midlands Airport apologized but defended their actions, stating that government regulations prohibit items resembling prohibited items from passing through security, including replica or model guns. The airport offered to post the toy back to the family's home in Doncaster, and James was bought a replacement toy after returning from their 10-day holiday.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend/wife. The ad offered accommodation, potentially a company car, phone, laptop, and gym membership to the successful candidate. 

His requirements included someone who loves pets, is preferably a non-drinker and non-smoker, is fit and attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, a good cook, and "great in bed." The ideal candidate should enjoy the outdoors but also be "a princess when need to be."

Rich described himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed, 175cm tall, with brown hair and eyes. He stated he doesn't drink, smoke, or do drugs, owns multiple properties, makes "great money," and is "WELL Endowed." He enjoys traveling, outdoors activities, sports, fishing, camping, cars, and bikes.

He promised he's "not shy of blowin cash on my woman" and that his partner would "receive lots of benefits." The ad specified that former partners need not apply and that "all reasonable offers will be considered." Daily Mail Australia attempted unsuccessfully to contact him.

FA chairman Greg Dyke is proposing radical changes to increase homegrown players in Premier League clubs, raising the minimum from 8 to 12 players per squad. He also wants to redefine "home-grown" to mean players trained in England for three years before age 18 (rather than before 21).

Five former England managers - Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren - have written a letter supporting Dyke's proposals, warning that blocking these changes risks England falling further behind leading football nations.

The managers cite concerning statistics showing only 81 of 220 Premier League starters (36.8%) in a recent round were eligible for England. They acknowledge that while England can produce talented young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane, these players lack sufficient opportunities.

Despite England's recent positive results under Roy Hodgson, the former managers believe the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level disadvantages any England manager and makes it harder to end England's wait for a major trophy since 1966.

The passage describes an episode of the TV show Poldark where Demelza Poldark gives birth to a daughter within the first ten minutes. The show's star, Aidan Turner's character Ross Poldark, is shown gazing lovingly at his newborn, having married Demelza (played by Eleanor Tomlinson) out of duty but clearly being in love with her. 

The passage highlights a major timeline inconsistency in the show's portrayal of pregnancy - Demelza goes from announcing her pregnancy in the previous episode to being eight months pregnant at the start of the next episode, then giving birth just minutes later. This unrealistic pregnancy timeline mirrors a previous storyline with another character, Elizabeth, who also went to full term between episodes. Fans noticed this issue and commented on social media about how pregnancies in Poldark seem to last only about 10 minutes.

Leicester City, bottom of the Premier League and three points from safety, have won their last two matches including a 3-2 victory at West Brom where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner. Manager Nigel Pearson is urging his players to stay focused on their own performances rather than worry about relegation rivals, warning against becoming "overly optimistic" despite their mini-revival. The Foxes host Swansea on Saturday as they fight to avoid relegation, with Pearson emphasizing that their survival remains in their own hands.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara set a new record for the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers) from Russia's Sakhalin Island across the Pacific Ocean to Baja, Mexico. This journey exceeded the previous record of 10,190 miles held by a humpback whale. 

The study was conducted by Oregon State University scientists, led by Bruce Mate, director of the Marine Mammal Institute. During her journey, Varvara visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, which surprised researchers. This behavior suggests Varvara may actually be an eastern gray whale rather than a western gray whale as previously thought, with Mate noting that her travel to Mexico indicates it's likely where she originated.

This discovery has important implications for whale conservation, as only 150 western gray whales are believed to exist. If some whales thought to be western grays are actually eastern grays, the endangered western gray whale population may be even smaller than estimated. The whale's ability to navigate across open water over such tremendous distances has prompted researchers to reconsider the genetic differentiation between eastern and western gray whale species.

A 1,000-foot stretch of seabed emerged overnight along the coastline of Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu on Japan's Hokkaido Island, rising 30-50 feet above sea level in some places. The new landmass measures approximately 1,000-1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide. Geologists believe the phenomenon resulted from a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which caused a section of land to drop and pivot the underwater area into the air. Local residents reported no tremors or sounds during the emergence, discovering the new coastline as a complete surprise the following morning. Marine organisms like seaweed and sea urchins remain attached to the exposed seabed. Authorities confirmed this event is unrelated to earthquakes and do not expect further expansion of the landmass.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, expressing his love for the club, city, and teammates. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Champions League match against Chelsea, the Dutch full back insists he is happy at PSG and wants to sign a new contract. He stated he accepts the coach's decisions and remains ready to play when called upon. However, PSG is reportedly interested in Barcelona's Dani Alves, which could potentially impact Van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez has been told to terminate his contract with Juventus to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. The 31-year-old striker, whose contract with the Serie A champions runs until the end of next season, has reportedly told Juventus he wants to leave this summer. 

Boca Juniors president Daniel Angelici confirmed they are close to completing a deal but emphasized that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus, which expires in 2016. Tevez began his career at Boca's youth academy in 1996 and scored 26 league goals in 76 appearances before leaving for Corinthians in 2005.

Despite being the Serie A's top scorer with 17 goals this season, Juventus have accepted Tevez's desire to leave and are already looking for replacements. Argentina manager Tata Martino stated that any potential move would not affect Tevez's international future, noting that both Juventus and Boca Juniors are great teams and it wouldn't be a step down.

During Bayern Munich's Champions League match against Porto at the Allianz Arena on Tuesday night, manager Pep Guardiola accidentally tore a hole in the left leg of his grey trousers, exposing his underwear. The incident occurred during an exciting match where Bayern defeated Porto 6-1, with a dominant 5-0 lead at half-time. Guardiola joked afterward that he would need to buy new trousers for the next match. Bayern secured their semi-final spot with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski, overcoming Porto's initial 3-1 advantage from the first leg. Guardiola also removed his suit blazer during the match's later stages.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three cars occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale in Brisbane's west on Wednesday afternoon. Ten people were involved, including four children. 

Four patients were airlifted by rescue helicopter: a 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries, a 5-year-old boy with chest pain, a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries, and a 6-year-old girl with abdominal pain. The first two were taken to Princess Alexandra Hospital.

Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were transported to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment. One person was trapped in their vehicle and freed by Queensland Fire and Rescue using hydraulic cutting equipment. The highway was closed for several hours with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch on Thursday, which he showed off on Instagram while comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider. The 26-year-old midfielder, who has scored 4 goals in 25 matches this season, is expected to start in Arsenal's crucial match against league leaders Chelsea on Sunday at 4pm. Arsenal currently trail Chelsea by 10 points with 6 games remaining. The team has been boosted by Jack Wilshere's return from a 5-month injury, though Arsenal legend Ray Parlour expressed concerns about Wilshere's injury record while praising him as "the future of the club."

Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to referee the Manchester derby on Sunday at Old Trafford, despite having sent off three players from United and City this season. He dismissed City captain Vincent Kompany while officiating Belgium's 1-0 win over Israel in a Euro 2016 qualifier on March 31, resulting in Kompany's suspension for Belgium's June match against Wales. In the Premier League this season, Clattenburg has shown only two red cards, both to United players: Tyler Blackett in the 5-3 defeat to Leicester and Luke Shaw in the 1-1 draw with West Ham. The derby has added significance as United moved one point above City following City's 2-1 loss to Crystal Palace, with both teams competing for second place behind Chelsea. While City have struggled recently, United are on a five-game winning streak. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official.

The passage describes a controversy involving federal MP Bob Katter, who accused the Queensland Government of treating MP Billy Gordon like "a little black puppet on a string." 

Billy Gordon was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party after being accused of domestic violence and admitting to withholding his criminal history from Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk. Despite this, Gordon announced he would remain in parliament as an independent, creating problems for the Government's razor-thin majority.

Katter, who is of Lebanese descent and represents the federal seat of Kennedy, claimed the Queensland Government assumed Gordon would resign from parliament entirely. He compared this to federal cases where MPs in similar situations were not expected to resign.

The statement sparked social media criticism over Katter's terminology. In response, Katter defended his use of the phrase "black puppet," explaining he used it because he is "dark" and from Cloncurry, and has personally experienced racist attitudes from major parties. He said he deliberately used the term to highlight what he sees as racial overtones in the Government's treatment of Gordon.

Katter also referenced federal MPs Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott as examples of independents who became "puppets" for the government, vowing that Gordon would not make the same mistake.

A 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois named Dayna Dobias, who was born with cerebral palsy, is creating dance videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about disabilities. Despite facing bullying and stares due to her condition, she aims to show that people with disabilities are capable and should not be judged or treated differently. Doctors initially warned her parents she might never walk, but she now dances, drives, and attends college like any other 19-year-old. Through her videos, including one dancing to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," she hopes to counteract misconceptions that people with cerebral palsy cannot do anything. Dayna has also begun doing motivational speaking at local schools to spread her message of looking past disabilities and treating everyone equally.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Manchester United striker Javier Hernandez, currently on loan at Real Madrid, is attracting interest from multiple clubs including MLS side Orlando City. Orlando, coached by Adrian Heath and captained by Kaka, sees Hernandez as a major commercial draw for their large Latin-American fanbase. The 26-year-old Mexican international has one year left on his contract and United are willing to sell for around £8 million. Eight European clubs are also interested, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. 

Separately, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who rejected their initial offer. PSG, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord have all contacted his father about a potential move. Pereira was on the bench for United's match against Aston Villa.

A gang of at least three people set a car on fire at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday. The incident began when the suspects approached the driver while he was pumping gas and attempted to carjack him at gunpoint. After the driver fled, the suspects poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger and ignited it while two passengers were still inside. Though no one was injured, the car's front end was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects remain at large. Surveillance video is being used in the investigation.

A southern Iowa chiropractor named Charles Manuel from Lamoni has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. Manuel signed an agreement admitting to his misconduct and agreed not to apply for license reinstatement for at least 10 years. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic released a report detailing the charges, which included bartering sex for services and recommending patients stop taking prescribed medications. Despite these serious allegations, Manuel received perfect five-star ratings from three patient satisfaction surveys on HealthGrades.com. His practice was listed at a residential address in Lamoni, and he must prove the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before he can resume practicing in Iowa.

A Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea north of Poland on Tuesday in what the Pentagon called an "unsafe and unprofessional manner." The U.S. crew reported the Russian pilot performed aggressive maneuvers at close proximity and high speed. Russia claimed the U.S. plane was flying toward their border with its transponder off, though U.S. European Command denied this. The Pentagon and State Department plan to file a diplomatic complaint with Russia. This follows a similar incident a year ago when a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of a U.S. RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk, which officials called one of the most dangerous close passes in decades. Such encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are common in Northern Europe and between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a hotel parking lot in Salt Lake City just days before President Obama's scheduled visit to Utah. The theft occurred overnight on March 27 at the Marriott Springhill Suites, located near the airport and close to the state's FBI office.

The rifle was secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains inside the agent's vehicle. The thief broke the rear passenger window and apparently tied a rope to the rifle case, using another vehicle's momentum to forcefully pull the case free, even ripping the window frame from the door. Police found skid marks, rope pieces, and the broken case handle at the scene.

Along with the sniper rifle, the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing and tools were stolen. While some items were recovered at a nearby Residence Inn, the rifle remains missing. The hotel lacked surveillance cameras, and the rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer.

The Secret Service was notified of the theft before Obama's visit but did not comment on whether security measures were increased. Police are unsure if the agent's car was specifically targeted.

A 71-year-old man named Luigi Costa is accused of killing his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Red Hill, Canberra. The alleged murder involved stomping on the victim's head, cutting his throat, and multiple stabbings in Freebody's dining room.

Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and testified that the accused was likely suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the killing. Evidence supporting Costa's compromised mental state includes:
- Triple 0 calls made during the incident showing fluctuating mood
- A trail of faeces from the crime scene to where police found Costa
- Signs of mental decline in the weeks, months, and possibly years before the incident

Professor Mullen stated that Costa's brain was compromised by dementia combined with alcohol, leading to a confused state where he wouldn't understand his actions or their consequences. The prosecution suggested Costa feigned memory problems, which Professor Mullen denied.

Costa's mental state is crucial to the case, as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

In Everton's 1-0 win against Burnley at Goodison Park, Ross Barkley missed a 10th minute penalty, which was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton. The penalty was awarded for a foul by David Jones on Aaron Lennon. Barkley took the penalty instead of regular penalty-taker Leighton Baines, who has an excellent record of 15 goals from 16 Premier League penalties. This incident reminded observers of a similar situation in January when Kevin Mirallas took a penalty instead of Baines against West Brom and also missed. Manager Roberto Martinez defended the decision, stating that Barkley was within his rights to take the penalty and that he likes having multiple penalty takers who can decide based on how they feel in the moment. Martinez noted that Romelu Lukaku would have taken it if he had been on the pitch. Despite the miss, Everton won the match thanks to a goal from Mirallas in the 29th minute.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has begun his role as Curacao's coach with success in World Cup qualifying. Curacao advanced to the second round of CONCACAF qualifying for the 2018 World Cup after drawing 2-2 with Montserrat (winning 4-3 on aggregate, having won the first leg 2-1).
