In 2011, the US poverty rate remained at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, after three years of previous increases. Real median household income declined by 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality increased by 1.6% as measured by the Gini index - the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%. The passage notes that poverty had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

The passage describes Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer who moved to Lancashire (the Red Rose) from Somerset in 2013. He has signed a new contract with Lancashire until 2019. Buttler is noted as a short-format specialist who holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including one scored in 46 balls against Pakistan. Cricket director Ashley Giles praised him as one of the most talented cricketers, highlighting his contribution to winning the T20 Blast final at Edgbaston and his positive influence in the dressing room. Buttler has been playing for Mumbai Indians in the Indian Premier League and will return to Lancashire for their T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

The passage describes four decommissioned Type 22 frigates (HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall) currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour that are up for sale. Bidders had until January 23 to register interest, with no preservation proposals submitted. Viewings are scheduled for late February and March, with a final decision expected in spring.

The government's Disposal Services Authority is handling the sale and wants at least one frigate to go to a UK ship recycler to test the UK's recycling capacity. Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt supports giving UK recyclers a chance but prefers at least one ship be converted to a reef and diving attraction for tourism revenue.

The Type 22 frigates were originally anti-submarine specialists that evolved into powerful surface combatants with comprehensive weapons systems and excellent command facilities, typically crewing about 280 personnel. The Ministry of Defence seeks the best financial return for taxpayers but won't comment on bids received. For context, HMS Ark Royal was previously sold for scrap for £3m.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant racial and political instability, marked by four coups over 20 years. The 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians overthrew an elected Indian-dominated coalition, leading to economic damage and international isolation. A 2000 coup led by George Speight held the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister and cabinet hostage. The most recent coup occurred in 2006.

These events severely impacted Fiji's economy, particularly tourism, and damaged its international reputation. Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 but was reinstated after holding free elections in 2014, which also restored diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand.

Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians (now a small majority) and Indo-Fijians (descendants of Indian indentured laborers), with minimal mixing and deep informal segregation between the groups. Many Indo-Fijians fled following the coups.

The economy relies heavily on sugar and tourism but is diverse, including mining (gold, silver, limestone), services, and light manufacturing. However, Fiji struggles with persistent trade and budget deficits, making it one of the world's largest per capita aid recipients.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad told the BBC that Syria is trying to comply with the chemical weapons destruction timetable despite missing Wednesday's deadline. He stated that a weapons shipment was attacked twice while being transported from Damascus to Latakia port, with the second shipment intercepted by "terrorist groups."

Syria has approximately 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, but only about 4% (30 tonnes) had left the country according to the US. Russia expects Syria to complete the transfer to the coast by March 1, with all weapons to be destroyed by end of June.

Mr Mekdad rejected US Secretary John Kerry's condemnation of barrel bomb use in Aleppo, where the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reports 246 people, including 73 children, were killed in five days. He denied bombing civilian areas and accused the US of supporting terrorist elements.

The Syrian government also denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison, though the Observatory reported an assault by Islamic Front coalition members that freed hundreds of detainees. The prison reportedly holds at least 3,000 detainees in horrific conditions.

Despite delays, Mr Mekdad emphasized Syria's commitment to its agreements with the OPCW and UN Security Council, stating they will implement all obligations on time.

The passage covers the 2014 Man Booker Prize shortlist and competition. Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others," set in 1960s Calcutta, is the bookmakers' favorite at 5/2 odds. This is the first year the prize is open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality.

The six shortlisted authors include three British writers (Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith), two Americans (Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler), and one Australian (Richard Flanagan). Jacobson, the 2010 winner, is nominated for "J," while other notable works include Smith's "How To Be Both," Ferris's "To Rise Again at a Decent Hour," Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves," and Flanagan's "The Narrow Road to the Deep North."

Fowler's book is the best-selling with over 55,000 copies sold. The shortlist announcement caused significant sales increases for all nominated books. Some critics, including Professor David Brauner, consider it a weak list, though he views Jacobson's "J" as the strongest contender.

The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night, with the Duchess of Cornwall presenting the prize. This is the 46th year of the Booker Prize, and shortlisted authors receive £2,500 and a special edition of their book.

A celebrity referred to as PJS is appealing to the UK Supreme Court after the Court of Appeal lifted a ban preventing media in England and Wales from naming him. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish allegations about his extra-marital activities, including "occasional sexual encounters" with person AB starting in 2009 and a three-way sexual encounter in December 2011 involving AB's partner CD.

The case history shows that in January, AB and CD approached the Sun on Sunday with their story. A High Court initially refused to grant an injunction, but PJS successfully appealed and obtained a ban on being identified. However, News Group Newspapers challenged this, arguing the story had already been published in the US, Scotland, and spread across the internet.

On Monday, Court of Appeal judges ruled that PJS was unlikely to obtain a permanent injunction because details were now "so widespread" that confidentiality had "probably been lost," despite his solicitors' efforts to remove online content. The judges gave PJS until Tuesday 10:00 BST to apply to the Supreme Court, with an interim injunction preventing publication until Wednesday 13:00 BST. The Supreme Court has now extended this interim injunction until the conclusion of the next hearing, where it will decide whether to grant an appeal and determine the outcome.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was recently purchased for £345.5m in August. The new owners are preparing plans to address parking and traffic congestion issues, as well as improve the appearance of the units. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White noted that the new owners view Fosse Park as a gateway from Blaby into the city and an investment opportunity for improvement, particularly addressing the current view of "backs of sheds." Paul Clarke from Crown Estates stated their focus is on resolving parking and congestion problems, and upgrading the common areas where people walk and park, as they believe the location has become tired in recent years.

The passage describes controversy surrounding Disney's Beauty and the Beast film in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" in the movie. The film was originally scheduled for release on Thursday but was held for content review. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film on Tuesday with "a minor edit concerning a gay moment" and gave it a P13 parental guidance classification. 

The controversy centers on a subplot involving the character LeFou, who experiences feelings of lust and admiration for the antagonist Gaston. Homosexual activity is illegal in Muslim-majority Malaysia, though the tourism minister called a potential ban "ridiculous."

Local cinemas have been offering refunds for pre-purchased tickets, and no new release date has been announced. The situation has drawn criticism from Malaysian netizens, who called the decision "stupid and laughable," with some pointing out perceived inconsistencies in censorship standards.

The passage describes Southampton City Council's efforts to regulate Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs). Landlords with properties housing more than three unrelated people must obtain an HMO licence costing £1,000, but many avoid doing so despite facing potential fines of up to £20,000. The council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in Southampton. 

Shelter adviser Nadeem Khan reports receiving 5-6 daily calls from HMO tenants concerned about eviction fears and poor property maintenance, attributing this to the shortage of affordable homes forcing people into unregulated rentals.

Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to houses with three or more storeys occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, specific licensing areas include Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (designated in 2013) and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (designated in 2015).

While most landlords have cooperated with the licensing regime, a small minority have resisted. The council has successfully prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Based on the passage, here is a concise summary:

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) are trying to avoid a second election in Ireland. Following an election almost two months ago, no party secured enough seats to form a majority government - Fine Gael won 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour 7. 

Fianna Fáil has offered to facilitate a minority government but will not support a programme for government. The main obstacle to reaching an agreement is water charges - Fianna Fáil wants them immediately removed while Fine Gael believes they should continue. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water (the national water utility) is being proposed as a potential solution. TDs have been unable to elect a taoiseach thus far.

The Sorrento ferry caught fire while traveling to Valencia, approximately 27km from Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon. The blaze started on a car deck and quickly became uncontrollable, forcing a full evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats. 

The evacuees were rescued by another ship, the ferry Puglia, and are being transported back to Palma de Mallorca. At least three people were injured and taken to hospital by helicopter, with one reported to be seriously hurt.

The fire's cause remains unclear. The ship initially sent distress signals at 13:50 local time, and while the captain initially thought evacuation might not be necessary, the fire's intensity ultimately required abandoning ship. The Balearic Islands port authority warned the Sorrento may sink in its current position. Psychologists are being arranged to provide counseling to survivors at the port.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs raised concerns about people, including students, allegedly voting twice in the June 8 election - a criminal offence. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote, with 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997.

The main issue identified was the high number of duplicate voter registration applications. Between December 2016 and May 22, 4.9 million applications were submitted, but the electoral register only increased by 1.4 million, suggesting 30-70% were duplicates in different areas.

This problem stems from the lack of connection between local electoral registers (managed by 381 separate authorities) and the online registration system. People cannot check online if they're already registered, leading many to submit multiple applications unnecessarily.

The Commission recommended:
- Better integration of electoral registers to identify duplicates
- Adding a verification function to check existing registration status
- Requiring people registered in two constituencies to declare in advance where they'll vote

While some people can legally register in multiple areas (students, second-home owners), voting twice in a general election is illegal with unlimited fines. Labour warned against making registration harder for young people and students who legitimately need registration in two places.

Lawrence Phillips, a 40-year-old former NFL player, is believed to have killed himself in prison on Wednesday. He was a star player at the University of Nebraska in the 1990s before playing for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999. Throughout his career and afterward, Phillips faced ongoing legal troubles, including convictions for assault - one for driving his car into a group of teenagers and another for assaulting a former girlfriend. He was serving a prison term of more than 30 years and had been placed in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward. A judge had just found sufficient evidence to try him for Soward's death on Tuesday, the day before his apparent suicide. His former Nebraska coach, Tom Osborne, described him as intelligent with good qualities but unable to overcome his anger issues.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram who serves as the official mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal at a ceremony in Chester marking the regiment's eighth anniversary. The promotion was awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams for "good behaviour." 

Derby XXX is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to 1858, when the first Private Derby was acquired by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot during the Indian Mutiny War. The tradition continued when the Mercian Regiment formed in 2007.

As an officially classed soldier, Lance Corporal Derby XXX has his own army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during mating season at the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. Since joining in February 2014, he has participated in various ceremonial duties, including switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Liverpool defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a dramatic Europa League match at Anfield, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time. Despite falling 2-0 behind in the first nine minutes through goals from Mkhitaryan and Aubameyang, Liverpool mounted a remarkable comeback. Manager Jurgen Klopp invoked the spirit of Istanbul 2005, urging his team to believe a comeback was possible. After Divock Origi pulled one back, Marco Reus restored Dortmund's two-goal advantage, but Liverpool scored three times in 33 minutes through Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and Lovren to complete the turnaround.

The match took place against the backdrop of the 27th anniversary of the Hillsborough disaster and featured an extraordinary atmosphere at Anfield. Klopp's passionate touchline presence and his philosophy of turning "doubters into believers" were central to the victory. The win moved Liverpool closer to the Europa League semi-finals and potentially a Champions League place. Klopp has forbidden his players from touching the famous "This Is Anfield" sign until they win something, adding another incentive for the team.

The passage describes a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London between UK government representatives and devolved administrations (Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland) regarding Brexit negotiations.

Key points from the meeting:

**UK Government Position (Mr. Davis):**
- Committed to keeping devolved nations updated on EU negotiations
- Proposed monthly meetings for "two-way information flow"
- Acknowledged different viewpoints but described the meeting as "constructive and amicable"
- Aims to work together for the best deal for the whole UK

**Scottish Government Position (Mr. Russell):**
- Welcomed the involvement process but criticized lack of transparency
- Complained that over four months after the referendum, UK government's strategic intentions remain unclear
- Highlighted uncertainty about whether UK wants to remain in single market or customs union
- Emphasized that single market membership is "essential for the economic prosperity of Scotland"

**Legal Development:**
- UK government hopes to overturn a High Court judgment on Article 50 triggering through Supreme Court appeal
- Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in this Supreme Court case
- Scotland's Lord Advocate James Wolffe intends to apply to be heard in the case

The passage reveals tensions between the UK and Scottish governments over Brexit strategy transparency and objectives, particularly regarding single market access.

The passage describes a study of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, including four clones (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane) created from the same cell line as Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal born in 1996. These four sheep are genetically identical to Dolly, making them her twin sisters.

The sheep are undergoing extensive physical examinations and monitoring by veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr and Professor Kevin Sinclair to address fundamental questions about cloning - specifically whether cloned animals age normally and remain healthy. The concern is that cloning from adult cells might transfer "age-memory," causing cloned animals to age prematurely.

This concern arose partly because the original Dolly died at six-and-a-half years old from a virus and had developed osteoarthritis, raising questions about premature aging in clones. To investigate, researchers are conducting comprehensive tests on the sheep, including joint X-rays and full-body MRI scans, focusing on three age-related conditions: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis.

The study's results, which could significantly impact the future of cloning science, were set to be published the following week. At the time of writing, the Dolly clones were approaching their ninth and tenth birthdays and appeared to be in good health.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Shutter Speed, ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes at 4-7 favorite, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters on soft ground. Trainer John Gosden walked the course before allowing her to race. This victory marked a fifth Musidora win for both Gosden and Dettori. Shutter Speed will next race at Chantilly rather than the Epsom Oaks, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are leading contenders.

In other races, Tasleet (14-1) won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas, with Jim Crowley riding.

Gosden has concerns about the ground conditions for his colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes and will walk the course again before deciding whether to run him in this Derby trial. The trainer noted he now has a month to prepare Shutter Speed for Chantilly, while there are only 16 days between the Dante Stakes and the Derby.

The passage describes currency and market volatility ahead of the UK's EU referendum vote. The pound fell against major currencies (down 0.2% against the dollar to $1.4226, down 0.6% against the euro, and down 1% against the yen), with the volatility index reaching levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis.

With 10 days until the referendum, two weekend polls showed the Leave campaign ahead, and betting firm Betfair reported the probability of a Remain vote had fallen from nearly 80% to 68.5%. This shift in polling caused investor uncertainty, with hedge funds short-selling sterling in expectation of further declines.

The uncertainty also affected stock markets, with Japan's Nikkei falling 3.5% and Hong Kong's main index dropping 2.5%. London's FTSE 100 ended down 1.1%, with Lloyds Banking Group falling 4.2%.

The Leave campaign, represented by Nigel Farage, argued that the pound had simply returned to March levels and that a weaker pound benefits UK exporters, noting that the UK trade deficit had narrowed in April due to increased exports.

The passage describes Braintree (the Iron) who are currently sixth in the National League, just outside the play-off spots by one point and place. They lost to Barrow, conceding an early goal after five minutes following a six or seven-hour journey. Manager Cowley praised his part-time team's efforts against a strong Barrow side, who extended their unbeaten run to nine games. Despite Braintree's three-game losing streak, Cowley remains positive about their "remarkable" achievements so far and acknowledges this as their toughest challenge yet, but one they will embrace.

The passage discusses upcoming changes to Northern Ireland's planning system, where from April 2015, local councils will take over planning decisions from the Planning Service (currently under Stormont's environment department). 

Currently, planning applications go to the Planning Service, which consults councils but retains final decision-making power. The reform will transfer this authority to elected politicians in local councils.

Opinions on this change are divided:

**Supporters** like Michael Corr (PLACE) see it as a positive opportunity for local councils to develop community plans and democratize planning.

**Critics** including Friends of the Earth's James Orr warn of potential risks:
- Historical precedent of discrimination in 1960s housing allocation by councils that fueled the Civil Rights movement
- Concerns about fairness and transparency without strict codes of conduct
- Worries about close relationships between developers and political parties
- Need for transparency in political donations, though this remains contentious due to security concerns and the fact that Northern Ireland parties typically don't attract large donations

The passage notes that decisions about transparency in political donations rest with the Northern Ireland Secretary.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun - twice in the shoulder and once in the back leg - in Winchburgh on March 14th. The cat survived but required amputation of its back leg. The Scottish SPCA called the cat "incredibly lucky" to survive and is investigating the incident. The case has reignited debate over air gun licensing in Scotland, with the Scottish SPCA urging the government to implement licensing urgently. However, a recent government consultation showed 87% of respondents opposed the proposed licensing scheme, which would require air gun owners to demonstrate legitimate reasons for ownership.

Liverpool have signed striker Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for £32.5m, making him their second most expensive signing. The 24-year-old Belgium international, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, signed a long-term contract after Liverpool triggered his release clause. This is Liverpool's seventh summer signing, following their sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City for £49m.

Benteke expressed his happiness at joining Liverpool, stating he came to win trophies and be part of manager Brendan Rodgers' project. The signing addresses Liverpool's goal-scoring problems from last season, when they finished sixth in the Premier League after strikers Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert managed only three league goals between them.

Liverpool have also signed forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and welcomed back Divock Origi from loan. Benteke, who missed the 2014 World Cup due to injury, scored 15 goals last season to help Villa avoid relegation and reach the FA Cup final. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge both praised the signing, highlighting Benteke's strength, pace, and ability to provide a different dimension to Liverpool's attack.

A study of 671 UK schools found that tablet computers are now used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with numbers expected to rise from 430,000 to 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. Academy schools showed the highest tablet usage, and 9% of schools provided individual devices for every pupil.

However, the research found no clear evidence that tablets improve academic results, though head teachers reported positive impacts, particularly in motivating disengaged pupils and increasing family involvement when devices were taken home. 

The study revealed extensive technology use among young people - in schools with one-to-one tablet programs, 25% of secondary pupils described themselves as internet "addicts," and two-thirds took devices to bed for social media and videos. A separate study suggested tablets were particularly helpful for boys and poorer pupils learning to read.

School leaders like Simon Mason advocate for tablets, arguing they create pupil empowerment and reflect modern life, though benefits are "difficult to put into league tables." The research concludes that while device types may change, technology in education will continue to grow.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs documenting children's lives in Liverpool spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s. The collection provides both a glimpse into childhood experiences and a social history of the city across more than 100 years.

The oldest photograph from 1887 shows the Rollo children - Florence, George, and Gertie - from a wealthy Waterloo Park family with four servants, dressed in fancy dress costumes for a mayoral ball. The exhibition also includes a portrait from around 1900 of a young maid working for a well-to-do Liverpool family, highlighting that many children were sent to work.

Curator Kay Jones selected these 25 images from hundreds in the National Museums Liverpool's collections, choosing photographs that best captured childhood experiences. She aimed to present both positive memories of children playing in the streets and the harder realities of child labor, showing both "the good and bad experiences of childhood."

The exhibition runs at the Museum of Liverpool until September 25th.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join National League rivals Torquay United. Anderson, who previously played for Aldershot, Exeter and in Italy, could face his former club on February 18th. 

Torquay have also signed 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating, who was recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating has played for Irish clubs Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, with his move pending international clearance.

Manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as having the leadership qualities he was seeking, while noting Keating is young and raw but eager to prove himself. Torquay currently sit four points above the relegation zone, having won just one of their last six games.

The passage describes a new law in Bolivia that permits 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera signed the law in President Evo Morales's absence, stating it reflects Bolivia's needs as one of South America's poorest countries. 

According to UNICEF, over 500,000 children already work in Bolivia to supplement family income, with many cleaning shoes and selling food in cities, while others work in extreme conditions in mines and agriculture. The government hopes the law will help eradicate extreme poverty.

The law also strengthens protections against violence toward children, setting a 30-year sentence for child homicide. 

While the International Labour Organisation typically says children under 15 should not work (or 14 in developing countries), Bolivia's government argues the law balances the country's reality with international standards. The ILO is currently studying whether the legislation breaches international child labor regulations.

A 50-year-old woman (O'Donnell) experienced a heart attack at home after helping someone struggling to get out of their car in Nyack village, near New York. She developed chest pain, nausea, and fever, then looked up "women's heart attack symptoms" online and took aspirin. The next day, she visited a cardiologist who inserted a stent into an artery that was 99% blocked. She learned her heart attack was called the "widow maker" type. Despite not calling 911 herself, she warned others to know the symptoms and call emergency services. O'Donnell, who has appeared in Drop Dead Diva, Will and Grace, and Nip/Tuck, shared her experience in a blog post titled "my heart attack." She previously hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network, which was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was stabbed and killed in an alleyway in Kenton at approximately 00:30 GMT on Saturday evening, following a party at Belvedere Way. He was pronounced dead about an hour later. 

The incident occurred after a fight with youths who were denied entry to the party, though police believe Che was not involved in this initial altercation but was targeted later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition at a north London hospital.

Police described the party as "a well-run event with appropriate adults in attendance" and confirmed Che had been invited. 

Three people have been arrested in connection with the murder: a 21-year-old man and two boys aged 15 and 16. The two boys have been bailed until mid-December. A 14-year-old boy was also arrested on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon. Police are seeking witnesses who were near the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate at the time of the stabbing.

The passage describes how Denmark reorganized its cancer diagnosis system after discovering alarming cancer survival statistics showing poor performance compared to other European countries over 15 years ago. The main problem was long waiting times for diagnosis, particularly for patients with vague symptoms or difficult-to-diagnose cases.

Denmark implemented a three-route model:

1. Fast-track routes for patients with "alarm" symptoms, with strict time targets and a law requiring investigation within 30 days of GP referral

2. Diagnosis centers (from 2007) where patients with symptoms GPs cannot diagnose receive multiple tests quickly, preventing "ping pong" between GPs and specialists

3. "Yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms unlikely to be cancer, offering quick tests or scans

The changes have shown positive results, with Denmark's survival rates improving at a faster pace than other Scandinavian countries and catching up to European standards. The reorganization was achieved within existing resources without flooding the system. A Welsh team of cancer specialists, GPs, and health experts visited Aarhus, Denmark's second city, to learn from this model, noting that Denmark's health system is similar to Wales in funding and organization.

Powys council has won a competitive bid to take over estate agent regulation duties from the disbanded OFT (Office of Fair Trading). The council will receive £170,000 annually to issue warnings and banning orders against dishonest estate agents or those breaching estate agent laws. While complaints will still go through local trading standards departments, cases involving potential breaches of the Estate Agents Act will be referred to Powys. James Munro from Powys council, who will lead the new team, sees this as an opportunity to demonstrate that Powys could handle more contracts and outside work in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce by expanding the roles of non-doctor staff through additional training. A Nuffield Trust review, commissioned by NHS Employers, found examples of nurses substituting for hospital doctors and pharmacists covering for GPs.

The report suggests these changes could help address gaps in junior doctor rotas and support overwhelmed GPs. It argues that with doctors comprising only one in 10 of the workforce, and with healthcare shifting toward managing long-term conditions like diabetes and heart disease, expanded roles for other staff make sense.

Examples of experimentation were highlighted, though specific details weren't provided in the passage. The report acknowledges that funding would be needed for implementation.

While NHS Employers and the report author see "huge opportunities" for improving patient care and creating more rewarding staff roles, unions and medical leaders expressed concerns. The British Medical Association warned against compromising doctor training or replacing doctors, emphasizing the irreplaceable nature of medical expertise. Unison cautioned that this shouldn't be viewed as a "quick and cheap fix" for staff shortages, noting that funding for training courses is often lacking due to budget constraints.

A crash at 03:00 GMT outside the First depot on Lower Bristol Road in Bath led to the closure of the A36 at Rackfield Place by Avon and Somerset Police. The road closure, which lasted until 14:00 GMT, caused significant disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations into the cause of the collision are ongoing. First bus services were affected, with the managing director stating that while some services had resumed normal schedules, full service recovery would take several hours, with hopes of normal operations by evening commute time.

The passage describes a dispute between Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) over the environmental impact of a proposed £1.3bn tidal lagoon project in Swansea.

Key points:

- NRW estimates the lagoon would kill 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually during migration
- TLP disputes these figures, claiming they lack "clear scientific basis" and that NRW refused to share its calculation methodology
- TLP's own computer modeling suggests a worst-case scenario of only 2% fish mortality across all species
- The Swansea project is intended as a test bed for larger tidal lagoons in Cardiff, Newport, and Colwyn Bay
- The UK government is reviewing the project's viability, with results pending
- The Welsh Government supports the scheme but seeks clarity from the UK government
- NRW strongly defends its figures, stating they are based on extensive evidence reviewed by independent experts over 18 months of discussions with TLP

The passage describes the announcement of a new agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland by Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster. The agri-food industry is described as "hugely important" to Northern Ireland, supporting almost 100,000 jobs across farming, fishing, retail and distribution. 

The marketing body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and will be similar to Scotland Food and Drink. Its purpose is to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities across both government and private sector organizations.

Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, noting that agri-food is a key sector for export-led economic growth and that industry representatives had identified a need for better coordination of marketing activities. However, she also noted that the new body could have implications for other organizations, including her own department, and expressed interest in discussing the plans with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a public tree-planting event on Saturday afternoon at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley. This is part of a four-year UK-wide project to plant millions of native trees commemorating those who died in WW1, using the pledge "We will stand for those who fell."

At Brackfield Wood specifically, the charity plans to plant 40,000 trees to honor the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who died in the conflict. The trust is inviting the public to participate in this hands-on memorial project.

Director Patrick Cregg emphasized this is a special opportunity for people to contribute to the wood while it's still in its early stages. The completed woodland will feature native trees, wildflowers including poppies, and will serve as a place for wildlife and for people to walk, relax and reflect.

The charity is providing saplings for volunteers, who are advised to wear wellington boots or sturdy footwear. Brackfield Wood is located about seven miles outside Derry city off the Glenshane Road, with limited parking available. The trees will serve as a lasting tribute to Irish soldiers and their families who were affected by the war.

The passage describes the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award ceremony in Harrogate. Hilary won the main award for "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller about domestic violence and honour crime featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. Judge Alison Graham called it "emotionally exhausting and powerful," while festival programming chair Ann Cleeves praised its fine writing and atmosphere.

US author Sara Paretsky received the outstanding contribution to crime fiction award for her 23-year career writing about female private investigator VI Warshawski. Cleeves noted that Paretsky was a "game changer" who created a strong female protagonist when it was uncommon, changing how readers viewed female crime writers. Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers globally.

The awards were presented at the start of Harrogate's annual crime writing festival in North Yorkshire.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old New Zealand cricketer, will return to Worcestershire for the 2017 season after his 2016 stint was cut short when he broke his finger in just his second game. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes described losing Santner as a "massive blow" to their qualification hopes. The left-arm batsman and spinner, who debuted for New Zealand in 2015, will rejoin the team after the ICC Trophy in June. Santner expressed frustration about his injury but enthusiasm about returning to make an impact. Worcestershire has also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for 2017.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in 2008 when struck by a speeding car while trying to hail a taxi on a Kiev dual carriageway. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina (Anna), had left him to retrieve a glove from a restaurant. 

A UK coroner ruled the death as unlawful killing, noting the car had stolen plates and didn't brake or stop. The couple had met online in 2006 and married after a four-day engagement in 2007. Ziuzina, 19 years younger than Pring, was revealed to be a lap dancer rather than the teacher she claimed to be.

Following Pring's death, Ziuzina quickly tried to claim his assets, sold his Range Rover and flat contents, and moved funds from his accounts. She was entitled to £200,000 from his estate and was having an affair with a Ukrainian man. 

Pring's family and friends believe his death was a staged hit-and-run for inheritance purposes. Ukrainian police initially closed the case but reopened it as a murder inquiry in 2011, though it remains inactive. Ziuzina did not attend the UK inquest despite attempts to secure her presence.

Charlie, a young boy from Merseyside who has been ill since age three, needs to return to Seattle Children's Hospital in America for experimental T-Cell Therapy unavailable in the UK. After his third relapse in April and the failure of his first T-Cell transplant, his family was left with no UK treatment options. An anonymous donor has paid for Charlie's treatment, leaving his parents Sophie and Rob Fearns "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed" by this generous act. The family received confirmation via email from the hospital on Wednesday that someone specifically requested to pay for Charlie's treatment. With financial clearance now secured, the treatment will begin as soon as possible, with the family expecting to receive a start date next week.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Apple has implemented two-step verification for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access following the theft and online posting of celebrities' intimate photos last month. The security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to their trusted device when logging in from a new device, in addition to their username and password.

Previously, third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker could bypass security and download complete iCloud backups even when two-step verification was enabled for other Apple services. The software's owner, Vladimir Katalov, confirmed that Apple's changes now prevent this workaround and that users receive email notifications when backups start downloading.

However, the two-step verification remains optional rather than default. Security expert Prof Alan Woodward suggests Apple should make it mandatory by default, allowing users to opt out if desired. Users who enable the feature receive a 14-character recovery key in case they lose access to their trusted device.

Apple CEO Tim Cook acknowledged the company's responsibility to increase security awareness and more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Based on the passage, here is a concise summary:

Former footballer Mark Wright is reportedly set to buy a 20% stake in Billericay FC and become a club director, though the deal's details are not yet finalized. Billericay currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points from a play-off position. The club was recently purchased by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has indicated he's willing to invest £10,000 weekly. Wright, who finished second in I'm A Celebrity in 2011, previously played non-league football for several clubs. The club recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

The passage describes a situation where Mr Ashley has been asked to give evidence to a parliamentary committee about the treatment of workers at his company. This follows a BBC investigation into warehouse working practices at the Derbyshire-based company.

Key points include:

- Mr Ashley received a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee

The passage recounts the author's experience covering the original iPhone launch by Steve Jobs in 2007. Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Barbara Windsor's final episodes as Peggy Mitchell. Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles last October. When police informed her parents Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles of her death, they immediately suspected Dhillon was responsible. 

Two days before the murder, Dr Hills had reassured Alice on the phone that she would be safe if she ignored Dhillon, despite her other daughter Emma warning that he might kill her. Dr Hills expressed deep guilt over dismissing these concerns.

The trial at Newcastle Crown Court revealed Dhillon had become obsessed with the 24-year-old Alice and stalked her. Her father acknowledged that none of them, including Alice, fully understood how serious the situation was despite warning signs.

Following their daughter's death, her parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking. They want Alice to be remembered for her "vibrant personality" and as someone who was always "smiling and laughing and making some sort of cheeky comment."

Dhillon, 26, was found guilty of murder despite denying the charge and was sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

French energy company EDF's board approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point nuclear power plant project in Somerset, with one-third of the cost coming from Chinese investors. Industry representatives urged quick government approval, warning that delays could lead to energy supply problems and higher costs. The project timeline shows it was first proposed in 2006, with construction approved in 2013, and has faced multiple delays since then.

The passage discusses concerns about a newly-designed divorce application form for England and Wales that asks for the name of the person a spouse committed adultery with. Family lawyers argue this addition increases conflict unnecessarily, as naming third parties is not typically required and complicates proceedings. 

The online form was updated to be more user-friendly, particularly for those not seeking legal advice. While guidance states it's "not normally necessary" to name the third party, lawyers worry people will feel compelled to fill in the box anyway. Named individuals become part of the court case, receive paperwork, and must respond - potentially causing delays and additional costs.

Statistics show adultery was the reason for 12,148 of approximately 100,000 divorces in England and Wales in 2015, with "unreasonable behaviour" being more common at 46,815 cases. Lawyers report that 80% of adultery-related clients want to involve the new partner, though judges disapprove of this practice.

The Ministry of Justice maintains there is no obligation to name anyone and that this option has always existed, though it's now more clearly presented in the new form.

The passage discusses concerns from the forestry industry that UK ministers are prioritizing environmental goals over commercial timber production. Key points include:

The passage describes a ceremony where Russian Defence attaché Captain Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to British veterans of the Arctic Convoys. These convoys were vessels that traveled from Britain to northern Russia during World War II to resupply the Soviet Union, facing constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, as well as severe weather conditions.

The Arctic route claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels by May 1945, with over 3,000 men dying during the campaign. Winston Churchill reportedly called it the "worst journey in the world."

The Foreign Office initially blocked Russia from awarding the medals in 2012, as British rules prohibited receiving foreign medals for acts that occurred more than five years ago. However, an exception was made in 2013, when President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his London visit.

91-year-old Able seaman Charles Lewis from Hampshire expressed being "honoured and delighted" to receive the medal, though he didn't consider himself a hero. The Russian Embassy emphasized the convoys' importance in providing weapons and ammunition that helped defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front, calling it a "material expression of our wartime alliance."

The British Government had previously created the Arctic Star medal in 2012 to recognize convoy veterans, but campaigners believed veterans should also receive the Russian recognition.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant problems with the unpaid work system for offenders in the UK. Their investigation of 100 cases revealed delays in starting work assignments and inadequate enforcement when offenders failed to attend. In one extreme case, an offender completed only 16 hours over 17 months after sentencing.

Unpaid work sentences, ranging from 40-300 hours, are given for offences like shoplifting, theft, drug offences, and criminal damage. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to complete such work, including garden maintenance, decorating, and litter-picking.

The report made 15 recommendations for improvement. Chief Inspector Paul Wilson criticized the system for treating unpaid work merely as punishment rather than an opportunity for rehabilitation, calling much of the management and delivery "simply not good enough."

Despite these failures, inspectors noted some positive aspects: instances of high-quality work, offenders gaining skills from using proper tools and equipment, and many offenders viewing their sentences positively while expressing determination to avoid future offending.

The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the problems as "totally unacceptable" and stated it was accepting all recommendations and taking action to implement them, emphasizing the need for more effective rehabilitation starting with ensuring offenders attend and face consequences when they don't.

The passage describes controversy surrounding comedian Russell Brand being called a "hypocrite" by The Sun newspaper. The criticism centers on Brand campaigning for economic and political revolution to help the poor while living in a luxury London home with wooden floors and exposed brickwork.

Brand has addressed these accusations of hypocrisy multiple times, acknowledging that he is rich and famous but arguing that:

- Economic disparity and ecological disaster are real issues that need addressing

Dr. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur who transformed the human genome mapping effort into a competitive race, earning criticism from the scientific community. Despite his reputation for immodesty and wealth, his work significantly accelerated genomics research.

Born in 1946, Venter initially pursued surfing before being drafted to Vietnam in 1967, where he served as a naval hospital orderly. This experience inspired him to become a doctor and instilled a sense of urgency about time.

Working at the National Institute of Health in the 1980s, Venter revolutionized gene decoding by focusing on messenger RNA molecules rather than entire genomes, dramatically increasing sequencing speed. After criticism and funding issues, he left NIH in 1992 to establish The Institute for Genomic Research, where he decoded the first complete genome of a free-living organism in 1995.

In 1998, Venter founded Celera Genomics to sequence the human genome in three years, competing with the public project. Both efforts published results in 2001. His unconventional approach and restricted data access drew criticism but generated significant financial rewards.

In 2006, he formed the J Craig Venter Institute, which spent over a decade creating Synthia, the world's first synthetic life form, published in Science journal. Venter has also conducted ocean expeditions on his yacht to collect and sequence marine microbe genomes. He believes synthetic microbes could create a new industrial revolution, potentially helping reduce oil dependence and capture carbon dioxide.

A new study presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting reveals significant glacier retreat in the French Alps over the past 40 years. Researchers from the University of Savoie found that ice fields in the region, including those around Mont Blanc, have shrunk from approximately 375 square kilometers in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 square kilometers by the late 2000s—a 26% loss.

The study examined roughly 600 glaciers across several massifs including Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, Grande Rousse Arves, and Mont Blanc. Using map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs with manual verification, researchers found that glacier retreat has accelerated since the mid-1980s, when coverage was about 340 square kilometers.

The retreat varies by region, with southern sectors experiencing the greatest losses. The Belledonne Massif has lost almost all its glaciers, while the Ecrins Massif shows retreat three times stronger than Mont Blanc Massif in the north. This difference is attributed to lower elevations in the south and varying climatic conditions, with the north receiving more precipitation and cloud cover. La Mer de Glace, France's largest glacier on Mont Blanc, has remained relatively stable, shrinking only slightly from 31.5 to just over 30 square kilometers.

PETA wants Skegness to replace its Jolly Fisherman mascot with an animal-friendly alternative, suggesting a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway for 12 guineas to promote train travel to the Lincolnshire resort, featuring the slogan "Skegness is so bracing." PETA's Dawn Carr argues the mascot represents animal cruelty, depicting fish being impaled and caught in nets. She believes changing the mascot would rebrand Skegness as a progressive destination that doesn't celebrate killing sea animals. However, Skegness Mayor Carl Macey says the Jolly Fisherman is beloved by adults and children and doesn't portray animal cruelty. While the suggestion will go before council, he indicated there likely won't be much support for removing the mascot, stating "if it isn't broken we won't try and fix it."

Scotland defeated Georgia in a rugby match with a final score that saw Scotland score six tries. Georgia opened the scoring through scrum-half Vasil Lobzhanidze's early try. Scotland responded with first-half tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try (resulting in Georgia's Kote Mikautadze being sin-binned), Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg, with Greig Laidlaw converting successfully. 

In the second half, Hamish Watson scored Scotland's fifth try early on. Georgia fought back with Lobzhanidze scoring his second try from a dominant scrum, and Scotland's Moray Low was yellow-carded for scrum infringements. Scotland finished strongly with Hogg scoring his second try following good work from debutant Ali Price and substitute Rory Hughes.

Scotland dominated possession in the first half (91% after 30 minutes) and managed the game well despite Georgia's strong scrum performance. Head coach Vern Cotter praised his team's pragmatic approach and game management.

Widnes defeated Castleford 38-31 in a rugby league match. Widnes led 14-6 at half-time through tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, while Castleford's Paddy Flynn (on loan from Widnes) scored against his parent club.

In the second half, Flynn scored again early, but Widnes extended their lead to 38-12 with additional tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor. Castleford mounted a late comeback with three tries in four minutes from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn (completing his hat-trick), but Widnes held on for the victory.

The win moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained sixth, one point above Widnes. This was Castleford's fourth consecutive home league defeat, while Widnes had previously lost nine of their last 10 matches.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, was released from Guantanamo Bay after being detained since 2002. A US review panel determined he was no longer a "continuing significant threat." He had been arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of al-Qaeda and Taliban links, charges he denies. Al-Odah claimed he was in Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. He challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. Upon release, he boarded a Kuwaiti government plane and now faces at least a year at a rehabilitation centre in Kuwait. His release, the first since May's Taliban-Bergdahl prisoner exchange, reduces Guantanamo's population to 148 inmates. The facility opened in January 2002 following 9/11, and President Obama has repeatedly promised to close it.

The passage describes the viral success of "PPAP" (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen), a catchy song performed by DJ Piko-Taro, a fictional character created by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka. The simple lyrics involve combining a pen with an apple and a pineapple. The 40-year-old creator explained he made the song while playing around with music.

The minute-long video, featuring an addictive beat, silly lyrics, and simple dance routine, was first uploaded to Piko-Taro's YouTube channel, gaining over 4 million views. However, when shared on Facebook by 9GAG, it exploded to over 44 million views. 

Viewer reactions were mixed - some found it addictively amusing while others found it irritating. Comments noted Piko-Taro's unique wardrobe, comparing him to a manga character. Despite international success, the song hadn't particularly trended in Japanese media or social networks at the time.

The viral success spawned hundreds of tributes and covers, including versions by Japanese duo Riko and Rika, a heavy metal tribute, and a cover by Thai social media star Happy Polla. Some compared Piko-Taro to Psy, suggesting this might have been deliberately designed to become a global phenomenon.

The passage describes Anzac Day commemorations in London, which honor Australian and New Zealand forces from World War One. Thousands attended an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, followed by a parade of up to 400 people and wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand Army Corps (Anzac) forces during World War One - specifically the Gallipoli landings. The tradition in London began in 1916 when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service, one year after the Gallipoli campaign.

Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer addressed the dawn service crowds, reflecting on the courage and heroism of Anzac troops. The ceremonies included veterans' associations, service personnel and their families in the parade, with crowds of expatriates lining the streets. The events featured prayers by schoolchildren and the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK.

The passage notes that the eight-month Gallipoli campaign in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of the war, representing an allied attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the conflict. These annual services have become an important tradition for expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders to honor their countrymen and women's sacrifices in all wars.

David Clarkson, a 30-year-old striker, has joined St Mirren from Premiership club Motherwell (Well) on his second spell there since July. The Scotland international, who has 2 caps and 1 goal for his country, scored 9 goals for Dundee last season and has nearly 400 senior club appearances throughout his career with teams including Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. The passage describes problems with a new chain ferry at Cowes. In response, council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until July 2 to acknowledge the problems and gather feedback, and ordered an audit review of the project. Local businesses have been severely impacted, with shopkeeper Angie Booth reporting nearly six months of lost trade and uncertainty about her business's survival.

Transport councillor Ian Ward characterized the issues as "teething problems" with a prototype vessel, noting that electrical problems have been fixed and ramp extensions are being manufactured to prevent vehicle damage. He attributed the groundings to seamanship issues that have been resolved. Compensation for affected businesses remains under discussion.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit for the UK fishing industry. Key points include:

Timothy Geaney, a 69-year-old teacher, admitted to taking or permitting indecent images of children between April 2004 and February 2014. The images were mostly of young boys partially dressed in erotic poses. In early 2023, he received a community payback order and was placed on the sex offenders register, and was ordered to participate in a special program for sex offenders.

Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, Geaney was removed from the teaching profession's register. The panel determined his conduct was "fundamentally incompatible" with being a teacher and that he failed to uphold professional standards. Forward Evans expresses concern about missing out again after Scotland lost in play-offs for Euro 2013 and the previous year's World Cup. She describes the potential of another failure as "devastating" and "heartbreak."

Iceland, ranked 20th in the world (one place above Scotland), are also unbeaten with four wins. The outcome of Friday's match and the return fixture on September 20 will likely determine the group winner. The best six of eight group runners-up will also qualify automatically for next summer's finals in the Netherlands.

Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, is one of 12 Scottish players based abroad out of the current 20-player squad. She recently won the women's Bundesliga in her first season at Bayern and celebrated with the men's team, including players like Franck Ribery and Arjen Robben.

Evans believes having more Scottish players in top leagues worldwide benefits the national team as they pursue their first major finals appearance. She notes that veteran goalkeeper Gemma Fay has been trying to reach a major tournament for 15 years.

A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform found no "magic bullet" to fix defects in Scotland's local tax system. The review, conducted by Prof Kenneth Gibb from the University of Glasgow, examined local taxation systems worldwide.

Key findings include:

- The current council tax has had "built-in problems from day one" and failure to modify it has created more difficulties
- Property taxes are used by almost all OECD countries and are considered "good taxes" because they're stable and difficult to avoid
- However, property taxes generate confusion about whether they tax wealth or pay for services, and some view them as unfair since they're not linked to current income
- Local income taxes are perceived as fairer but create income fluctuation problems for local authorities and offer little flexibility for local priorities

The Commission on Local Tax Reform, established by the Scottish government and council body Cosla, plans to hold public consultations across Scotland before publishing its report in autumn. The Scottish government considers the current council tax system "unfair" and awaits the commission's recommendations for alternatives.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Apple has implemented two-factor authentication for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access following celebrity photo thefts last month. The security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to their trusted device when logging in from a new device, in addition to their username and password.

Previously, third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker could bypass security and download complete iCloud backups even when two-factor authentication was enabled for other Apple services. The Moscow-based company's owner, Vladimir Katalov, confirmed his software was likely used in the celebrity hacks but acknowledged Apple's new implementation now blocks this technique.

Key concerns remain:
- Two-factor authentication is still optional rather than default
- Users risk losing access if they lose both their trusted device and 14-character recovery key
- Apple now sends email notifications when backups start downloading

Security experts, including Prof Alan Woodward from the University of Surrey, argue that two-factor authentication should be mandatory by default across all major tech companies. Apple CEO Tim Cook told the Wall Street Journal that the company plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable the feature and use stronger passwords, acknowledging a responsibility to increase security awareness.

The passage details campaign spending for the May European Parliament election. UKIP won the election and spent £2,956,737, while the Conservative Party spent £2,980,815. The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 but lost all except one of their MEPs. Labour came second and spent £1,027,339. 

The campaign period ran from January 23 to May 22 (polling day). When calculated per vote received, UKIP spent 68p per vote, Labour 26p, Conservatives 79p, and the Lib Dems £1.45. The Green Party, which finished fourth, spent £534,249 (43p per vote).

The six highest-spending parties, including the SNP which spent £267,372, spent a combined total of £9,347,087 on campaigning according to the Electoral Commission. All parties except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign.

The passage covers two player signings by a football club (the Gulls/Torquay):

1. **Myles Anderson** - A 27-year-old centre-back who cancelled his contract with Barrow to join the Gulls. He previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. He could play against his former club Barrow on February 18th.

2. **Ruairi Keating** - A 21-year-old striker recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. He has played for Irish clubs Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. His transfer is pending international clearance.

Manager Kevin Nicholson describes Anderson as a leader-type player he's been seeking, while Keating is characterized as young, raw, but hungry. The Gulls are currently struggling, sitting four points above the relegation zone in the National League with only one win in their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, narrowly beating Thistlecrack. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse died from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, which is rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues.

The horse, owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling), but had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms on Saturday. Many Clouds had notable previous victories including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

Trainer Oliver Sherwood called him the "horse of a lifetime." The BHA's report concluded that despite questions about whether his previous overheating issues were connected to his death, he had no significant underlying health issues and was the victim of a rarely seen haemorrhage on the racetrack.

The passage describes the final parliamentary session for several MSPs who are stepping down ahead of the May 5 election. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became emotional during farewell speeches from veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond.

Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007-2014, used his valedictory address to emphasize that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" and called for the parliament to assume greater responsibility for Scotland's governance. He welcomed new powers being transferred to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but maintained it didn't fulfill referendum campaign pledges. His speech included light-hearted moments, joking about competing with the Cheltenham races and wishing electoral candidates luck with "varying degrees of enthusiasm."

Duncan McNeil, an MSP since the parliament's establishment in 1999, delivered a powerful speech that moved Marwick to tears. He warned that Holyrood needed to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding committee systems and ensuring proper accountability and scrutiny.

Former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also gave a farewell speech, joking about missing her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Marwick thanked all departing MSPs for their service to parliament and Scotland.

The passage describes the casting and production details of Disney's live-action Beauty and the Beast film. Emma Thompson will play Mrs Potts (the teapot), with Kevin Kline as Maurice, Belle's father. Emma Watson stars as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as villain Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Directed by Bill Condon, filming begins at Shepperton Studios in May, with a US release date of March 17, 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce charging decisions regarding the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster at an 11:00 BST meeting with victims' relatives. The disaster killed 96 football fans during an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest on April 15, 1989. 

In January, evidence files for 23 suspects were submitted to the CPS - 15 related to Operation Resolve investigating the disaster's causes, and 8 concerning police conduct afterwards. Last year's inquests concluded the fans were unlawfully killed.

Relatives will learn the decisions at a private meeting in Warrington from Sue Hemming, head of the CPS's special crime and counter-terrorism division. Margaret Aspinall, whose 18-year-old son died and who chairs the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expressed hope this marks the end of their long struggle for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous recent incidents of packages being thrown over its walls. A former inmate described the jail as "notorious" for being "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. Local residents have witnessed these incidents, with one woman reporting seeing packages thrown over the wall four times in two weeks. The prison has arranged meetings with residents to discuss how to handle packages that land in their areas. While a former inmate claimed drones were used to deliver contraband directly to prison windows, the Ministry of Justice stated there was no evidence of drone activity at Chelmsford. The Ministry acknowledged that while staff work hard to prevent contraband, more needs to be done, and the Justice Secretary has requested an examination of tools needed to address the problem. New laws have been introduced that could result in up to two years imprisonment for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls.

A 72-year-old lollipop lady named Sylvia Blackburn suffered serious head injuries when she was struck by a car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. The driver, 55-year-old Brian Wright of Kempston, told Luton Crown Court he had been blinded by the setting sun when his VW Golf failed to stop at a red light and hit Mrs Blackburn. She had been on duty for 20 years and was escorting a woman and six-year-old child across the road when struck. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright accepts he hit her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. He expressed remorse in court, saying he was "truly sorry" and had turned her "world upside down." The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her final year veterinary medicine exams scheduled for May. She recently finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships in London, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m. Despite being disappointed about missing the Commonwealth Games, Muir prioritizes completing her degree. She is considering competing at the World Indoor Championships in Birmingham in March and believes she has at least two or three more Olympics ahead of her. The 5,000m race was won by Hellen Obiri, with Muir completing her fifth race in 10 days.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man, went missing in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party. A search began on Saturday morning at a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, beside the R112 near the River Liffey. The search involves excavations and is expected to take several weeks.

Earlier this year, six detectives began reviewing the case. Enhanced CCTV footage shows Deely talking to an unidentified man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where Deely worked. He had returned there to get an umbrella after the party. The same man was later captured on CCTV following Deely on Haddington Road.

Police released the footage in April and have renewed their appeal for the man in black to come forward, as he remains unidentified.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th after missing over two years due to injury, defeated Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 in his first Grand Slam since the 2014 Australian Open. The 27-year-old Argentine, who had three wrist operations during his absence, lost the first set but fought back to win. He will face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next and is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray.

Nick Kyrgios (15th seed) came from behind to beat Dustin Brown 6-7 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 in a rain-affected match, setting up a third-round meeting with Feliciano Lopez, who also came from two sets down to win. The winner will potentially face Murray in the last 16.

Other results included routine victories for 10th seed Tomas Berdych (6-4 6-1 6-2 over Benjamin Becker) and 12th seed Jo-Wilfried Tsonga (6-1 6-4 6-3 over Juan Monaco).

Tunisia and Morocco faced potential exclusion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations but have now been cleared to participate. 

Tunisia was threatened with expulsion after lodging complaints against CAF following a controversial quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 tournament. Tunisia was leading 1-0 in the 90th minute when a contentious penalty was awarded against them, leading to a 2-1 extra-time defeat. Tunisia wrote a furious letter to CAF criticizing the referee selection but denied accusing anyone of corruption. CAF demanded an apology by March 31, 2015, or Tunisia would face disqualification. After a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou in Senegal, Tunisia apologized and the matter was resolved.

Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns, requesting a 6-12 month postponement just two months before the event. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) overturned the ban and reduced Morocco's fine from $1 million to $50,000. Equatorial Guinea stepped in to host the 2015 tournament with only 64 days to prepare.

Both countries participated in the 2017 qualifying draw, with Tunisia drawn in Group A and Morocco in Group F. If Tunisia qualifies for the 2017 finals in Gabon, it would be their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance, setting a record.

The passage discusses McLaren's dramatic fall from being one of Formula 1's most successful teams to struggling for competitive results. Despite having won 182 grands prix (23.18% win rate), 12 drivers' championships, and 8 constructors' titles, the team is now hoping for just fourth place on the grid and some points.

Key information covered:

**Current situation**: McLaren has two world champions driving for them, including Fernando Alonso, but struggles with poor performance due to Honda engine problems, though the chassis has improved.

**Historical success**: The team's greatest era was with Honda (1988-1992), winning 15 of 16 races in 1988 with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. They also succeeded with Mercedes engines and Mika Hakkinen in 1998-99.

**Recent decline**: Problems began in 2013 with chassis design issues. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998, and they haven't won races since 2012 when Lewis Hamilton and Jenson Button won seven races between them.

**Scandals**: In 2007, McLaren was excluded from the constructors' championship and fined $100m for possessing Ferrari technical information. In 2009, they faced "lie-gate" involving Hamilton and sporting director Dave Ryan.

**Leadership**: Ron Dennis, who transformed the team in the 1980s, returned to control in 2013 after stepping back in 2009, but hasn't yet reversed the decline.

**Future outlook**: Dennis believes McLaren will eventually break Mercedes' dominance and win "championships, plural" again, citing progress with the car design and expected Honda engine improvements.

On October 6, 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 6:00 AM for a sudden death. When police arrived, they found people still at the bar, with till receipts showing alcohol was served until 4:49 AM. The license holder, Colleen O'Neill (43), and James Thomas (44) were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours. The court heard that licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly followed and the bar had been operating improperly into the early morning. The judge, noting Ms. O'Neill's "appalling record," ordered the bar closed for three months and fined her £3,000, while Mr. Thomas was fined £1,000. Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, hitting 8 three-pointers to surpass his previous mark of 272. LaMarcus Aldridge led Portland with 27 points.
