YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen visited Liverpool's Melwood training ground, where he met players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic. The Liverpool players were initially told van Velzen was a competition winner receiving a dead-ball masterclass, but they quickly realized he was actually a skilled player when he demonstrated his impressive free-kick abilities. Van Velzen, who has gained fame on YouTube for his free-kick videos, pretended to be an amateur at first before revealing his true skills, surprising the Liverpool players. He expressed that meeting Balotelli and playing with his idols was "every fan's dream." The session ended with van Velzen unveiling Balotelli's famous "Why Always Me?" slogan from his Manchester City days.

A Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutations found that removing ovaries (oophorectomy) after breast cancer diagnosis significantly improves survival rates. Women with BRCA1 mutations who had the procedure showed a 62% reduction in breast cancer death risk, with a 20-year survival rate of 77.4% for the entire group. The protective effect was strongest when surgery occurred within two years of diagnosis (73% reduction in death risk). However, the benefit was not observed in BRCA2 carriers. The study, published in JAMA Oncology, also found a 65% reduction in death from all causes and prevented nine ovarian cancer deaths. The research supports Angelina Jolie's decision to have the procedure in March after her 2013 double mastectomy, as women with these mutations face up to 70% lifetime breast cancer risk.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina, shortly before 10 AM. The train, the Carolinian No. 80, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City with 166 passengers aboard. None of the passengers were injured, though one man who became ill during the delay received medical treatment. The couple was pronounced dead at the scene, and the train was delayed for approximately 2 hours and 45 minutes before continuing its journey. According to a local man who had previously encountered the couple while collecting scrap metal, they may have been living in a homeless camp. The accident occurred on property owned by Norfolk-Southern, about 25 miles northwest of Raleigh, the train's next scheduled stop.

A 66-year-old former Medellin cartel member named Carlos Toro faces deportation after working as an unpaid DEA informant for 27 years. Toro fled Colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss and began cooperating with the DEA, providing crucial information that helped prosecute major figures including cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite promises of U.S. citizenship in exchange for his service, Toro remains in the country illegally after retiring due to declining health. The DEA refused to help with his citizenship after he went public with his situation. Toro fears returning to Colombia would mean certain death within hours. He cannot collect social security benefits without proper documentation, and his temporary visa expired on January 1. A former DEA handler who worked with Toro gave him $5,000 for an operation and criticized the government's treatment of him.

The US internet regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal practices with the new '.sucks' domain name. The company has been charging celebrities like Kevin Spacey and major companies approximately $2,000-$2,499 per year to secure their '.sucks' domains before they become available to the public. Major brands that have purchased domains include youtube.sucks, bing.sucks, visa.sucks, bankofamerica.sucks, and yahoo.sucks. 

ICANN has contacted the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs after an advisory panel of companies including Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay complained, calling it a "shakedown scheme." While Vox Populi claims the domains are meant for companies to interact with critics, critics argue the company is using the threat of releasing these domains to consumers for just $10 a year (starting September) as coercion to force expensive defensive purchases. Taylor Swift has also previously had to spend money to remove her name from '.adult' domains.

A baby boy's body was found floating in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk in June 1988. The case remained unsolved for 27 years until police exhumed the body in 2014 during a periodic review. Using DNA technology, they matched samples to the national database and traced the baby's mother.

The woman, who remains unnamed, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but explained that the baby was stillborn. She had concealed her pregnancy from family and friends, gave birth alone in secret, and placed the baby in the pond just days before teenagers discovered it.

Police determined there was no foul play involved. The woman remains on bail while authorities decide whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

The baby was originally buried by villagers who raised funds for the funeral. After the investigation, he was reburied in June 2014 at St Peter's Church with a new headstone naming him "Peter" after the church. A stillbirth support charity called Hana's Gift paid for the new memorial.

A taxi driver must pay compensation to a passenger who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from his moving vehicle five years ago. Kristopher Hicks, now 27, was traveling home from a night out in Bath with his girlfriend when driver Michael Young, 56, mistakenly believed Hicks planned to leave without paying. Young decided to drive Hicks back to the taxi rank to "teach him a lesson," continuing for almost a mile despite objections. Hicks jumped from the taxi while it was traveling over 20mph, resulting in devastating brain injuries and epilepsy, requiring 24-hour care from his mother. The High Court ruled Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages set at around 50% of the requested amount - likely hundreds of thousands of pounds. The judge found Young created significant risk to life despite not intending serious harm.

Tornado sirens sounded Wednesday night in Kansas as severe storms brought multiple tornado reports. Spotters confirmed a tornado 6 miles northwest of Goddard (near Wichita), which moved northeast, avoiding the city. Three additional tornado sightings occurred near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. The storms also affected Missouri, where a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage and flooding. The town of Farmington experienced baseball-sized hail. Weather experts warned that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous, and more storms were expected Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and southern Great Lakes region.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to fight in a middleweight bout in New Jersey on Saturday. Rockhold, seeking his fourth consecutive win since losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago, plans to be aggressive ("the bull") against Machida's evasive style ("the matador"). He intends to cut off Machida's movement and force him to fight on his terms, believing he has advantages both standing and on the ground.

Rockhold respects Machida as a long-time top fighter and martial artist but is confident in his superior "hip movement and speed." He's been training intensively, "running marathons every day" to prepare for chasing down the elusive Machida.

Machida, coming off a victory against CB Dollaway in Brazil, believes he can win by applying his technique and strategy. He notes that the winner of this fight deserves a title shot, as another planned title eliminator between Jacare and Yoel Romero is also in line. Machida completed an eight-week training camp with Glover Teixeira and feels well-prepared for the fight.

Both fighters acknowledge mutual respect but are focused on victory and the potential title shot that awaits the winner.

A light aircraft attempted to land at Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida without deploying its landing gear. The Aerostar plane touched down on its belly, with its propellers hitting and ricocheting off the runway while the wings bounced from impact. Upon realizing the mistake, the 85-year-old pilot Chris Georgaklis, who has nearly 50 years of flying experience, gave full throttle and managed to take off again despite the damaged propellers. He then flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where he landed safely, accompanied by his dog Buddy. The incident, known as a gear-up or belly landing, is typically caused by human error or mechanical failure. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performances this season but pledged to support him until the end of the campaign. City are willing to listen to offers for the Ivorian midfielder, who has two years remaining on his £220,000-a-week contract, as they plan to overhaul their aging squad. 

City's poor form has seen them take just 18 points from 39 available, putting their top-four position at risk with Liverpool potentially closing the gap. The team will face West Ham without injured captain Vincent Kompany. Goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledged the players have let Pellegrini down despite backing the manager.

Meanwhile, West Ham's Aaron Cresswell has attracted interest from Chelsea and Manchester City. Manager Sam Allardyce warned the 25-year-old left-back about potentially making the same mistake as Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who moved to City but rarely played.

A Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "godfather of Uxbridge," Domenico Rancadore, will be allowed to remain in the UK after his Italian sentence was dropped. The 65-year-old, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years under the alias Marc Skinner, was convicted in absentia in Italy in 1999 and given a seven-year sentence for being a member of the Cosa Nostra.

After losing his extradition battle in February, it emerged that his case expired in October 2014 under Italian law, which states that sentences are extinguished after double the penalty period has passed. His European arrest warrant will be withdrawn, though the Italian Supreme Court must still hear the case.

Rancadore, known as "the Professor," fled Italy in 1995 and was convicted for his role as a "man of honour," taking bribes from builders in Palermo. He was first arrested at his London home in August 2013. During extradition proceedings, concerns about Italian prison conditions and his serious heart condition initially blocked his return.

Legal experts criticized the waste of time and money on the case, with the CPS admitting to administrative errors that contributed to delays. Rancadore's neighbors described him as quiet and suffering from ill-health, expressing relief that he would remain in the community.

AP McCoy will ride Mr Mole in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, which will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre (ridden by Nico de Boinville). The seven-runner field also includes Somersby. McCoy announced his retirement from racing after winning on Mr Mole at Newbury in February. His complete schedule for his final day as a professional jockey will be confirmed Friday morning.

A mother, Virginia Trimble Ritter, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter Marcia, who was murdered 40 years ago in 1975. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett when she was a young girl. Her body was discovered 33 days after she disappeared, found 150 yards from her home in a garage, strangled and sexually assaulted with her cookie money missing. 

Ritter's husband had advised her against viewing the body or crime scene photos at the time, wanting her to remember Marcia as she was in life. However, Ritter regretted this decision and last year asked the lead investigator to show her the photos. Upon seeing them, she was horrified by her daughter's condition and expressed a desire for revenge.

The case remained Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years until Barrett was arrested in 2006 after DNA evidence linked him to the crime. In 2009, Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy believes it's "unthinkable" that he won't win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam. The world number one would become just the sixth player to win all four major titles, joining Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods.

McIlroy revealed that his final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011, where he lost a four-shot lead and shot 80, was the most important day of his career. He learned valuable lessons that helped him win his first major at the US Open two months later, followed by victories in the 2012 US PGA and both the Open and US PGA in 2014.

Despite having just one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, the 25-year-old views winning at Augusta as a career-long goal. He hopes to use the golf course as his "sanctuary" from the pressure and hype, as he did during his successful 2014 season despite personal challenges including calling off his wedding to Caroline Wozniacki and a costly legal dispute with his former management company.

According to the passage, 272 children disabled by foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized in England over the past 12 months, based on data from the official health and social care information centre. However, experts warn the actual number affected could be far greater, with World Health Organisation research suggesting at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer learning, behavioural and physical problems due to alcohol exposure in the womb - equating to about 7,500 babies annually.

The syndrome causes permanent disabilities including learning difficulties, behavioural problems, and physical issues such as deformed limbs. Other associated medical problems include liver, kidney and heart issues, cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy. 

The passage includes a case study of 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who requires help dressing, has no sense of danger, and will never live independently. She was diagnosed at age five after struggling at playschool.

Currently, pregnant women are advised by the government not to drink alcohol, or if they do, to limit consumption to no more than two units twice weekly. However, Elizabeth Mitchell from the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome believes guidance should be changed to advise no alcohol consumption during pregnancy, describing the condition as "an enormous problem" that is "vastly under-diagnosed."

A masked robber named Shaun Andrew McKerry, 31, attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15 at 8 pm while wielding an axe. As he demanded cash from assistant Andrea Brighty, shop owner Sab Dhillon tackled him to the floor. During the struggle, Dhillon's wife Sam hit McKerry twice with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him. Police arrived minutes later and arrested McKerry, who was bleeding from his nose. He pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court and was sentenced to six years in prison. McKerry, known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" in his youth for always returning home after crimes, has an extensive criminal history starting from age 12, including 80 arrests by age 15 and numerous convictions for various offenses.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with gang rape following an incident at a Canadian barracks and must remain in Nova Scotia until their trial. The accused - Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31), and Darren Smalley (35) - appeared in court in Dartmouth, near Halifax.

The sailors were given unusual bail conditions, including:
- Bail set at over £2,000 each
- Surrender of passports
- Required to live at Stadacona naval base in Halifax
- Must remain employed by the Royal Navy with current pay
- Cannot leave Nova Scotia or apply for new passports
- Forbidden from contacting the victim and six witnesses

The alleged sexual assault occurred on April 10 after the sailors, who were playing for the Royal Navy ice hockey team at Shearwater naval base, returned from a hockey game. The victim, a woman in her early 20s from Halifax, had attended the party with a friend.

The men are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, offences punishable by up to 14 years in prison. They are scheduled to return to court on May 27. The Crown prosecutor indicated that forensic test results could lead to additional charges.

A mother in Las Vegas was reported to police for child abuse after a stranger mistook her son's rare skin condition for signs of abuse. Four-year-old RJ Jackson is one of only 70 people worldwide with Netherton's syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease that makes his skin appear red, inflamed, and scaly. 

While shopping at Walmart, Valerie Jackson was surrounded by five armed police officers after someone called to report suspected child abuse. The 35-year-old mother must apply Vaseline to RJ's skin 2-3 times daily to prevent drying, and when he was younger, this was required every few hours, even at night.

The family faces regular discrimination, including being denied entry to play centers and receiving cruel comments from adults who assume RJ has been burned. Mrs. Jackson discovered her son's condition through online research after doctors couldn't diagnose him at birth. She found a Facebook support group for Netherton's syndrome that helped her identify and manage his symptoms.

Netherton's syndrome causes red, scaly skin and can lead to infections and allergies. There is no cure, though symptoms often improve with age. Despite the challenges and public ignorance, Mrs. Jackson describes RJ as a beautiful, happy child with a cheeky smile.

The passage describes the controversy surrounding Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" advertisements featuring bikini-clad model Renee Somerfield on the London Underground. Transport for London (TfL) confirmed the posters were being removed after their three-week advertising period ended. The ads sparked significant backlash, with over 50,000 people signing a Change.org petition for their removal, and the Advertising Standards Authority receiving over 200 complaints about promoting unhealthy body image. Many posters were defaced by protesters who objected to the implication that only women with the model's body type were beach-ready. 

Protein World defended their campaign on social media with controversial responses, including calling critics "fatties." The company's head of global marketing, Richard Staveley, appeared on Good Morning Britain where presenter Susanna Reid called the ads "anxiety inducing." Staveley revealed the company had received violent threats and a bomb threat, which was reported to police. A protest was planned for May 2 in Hyde Park. Despite the controversy, Staveley declared it a "fantastic campaign" and stated they wouldn't change their advertising approach. The passage also notes that protein powder sales in the UK were growing significantly, from £73m in 2007 to an expected £358m by 2017.

Rail companies are planning fare increases of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite party leaders' promises to freeze prices. 

Key points:
- Prime Minister David Cameron has written to First Great Western (FGW) requesting an "urgent review" of their decision to nearly double some fares on the London-Cotswolds route, which passes through his Witney constituency
- A specific example: off-peak returns from Charlbury to London will increase from £33.30 to £62.40 (87% rise) from May 17
- Both Conservative and Labour parties had pledged to freeze or cap fare increases
- Other significant increases include:
  - Crewe to Northampton first-class single: £30 to £37
  - Stafford to Liverpool anytime return: £26.50 to £33 (24.5% increase)
  - Manchester to Stoke first-class return: £29 to £35.30 (22% increase)
- Train companies can increase "unregulated" fares (about half their revenue) three times per year
- FGW claims the changes align the north Cotswolds route with other services
- Virgin defends its increases, stating their overall fare rise is 1.65%, below industry average

A 66-year-old former soldier, John Young, has been permanently blinded in one eye after being struck by a brick thrown by vandals at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The attack occurred on April 18 when Young and his new wife Elaine, 54, were writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts, having married just three weeks earlier. 

The incident began when thugs started throwing stones at their front window around 11 PM. When a brick smashed the glass, Young opened his front door to confront the attackers, only to be hit directly in the left eye with another brick. Despite emergency surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight.

Young, a retired HGV driver who previously served with the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers during the Irish Troubles, suffered an open wound to his forehead along with the eye injury. The couple, who met 14 months ago, now feel unsafe in their home and plan to relocate to Southport.

Police have launched an investigation but report no apparent motive for the attack, suggesting it may have been vandals "messing around." Detective Constable Gareth Gwilliam emphasized the serious consequences of what the perpetrators may have considered a prank, resulting in permanent disability for the victim.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper and former England under-19 international, has signed a one-year contract extension following his return from injury. He missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident in April that killed his father Keith. After undergoing ankle surgery, Poynton made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the season. His new contract extends through the end of the 2016 season. Derbyshire's elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton's exceptional character and tireless work in training since the tragedy, noting his good form since returning.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw from Stretford has been declared cancer-free after battling neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 UK children annually. He was diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs and bones after his mother took him to a doctor for stomach pain.

During his year-long treatment, Harley created a Ninja Turtle superhero mask by decorating the protective mask used during radiotherapy, which helped him feel stronger and braver. His story gained international attention, prompting Nickelodeon to send him Ninja Turtle presents for Christmas.

Harley's treatment included 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, surgery to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant (which caused complications he overcame), and weeks of radiotherapy at the Christie clinic in Manchester. His parents Oliver (25) and Stacey (23) received the news that he is now cancer-free, though he will require regular check-ups in coming years.

For his bravery, Harley received a Cancer Research UK Little Star award and became the face of their Kids and Teens campaign. His father reports that Harley is doing well, running around and hoping to return to school full-time soon.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player who impressed in their FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, is at the center of an international tug-of-war between the Republic of Ireland and England. Villa manager Tim Sherwood believes Grealish should focus on his club career before making his international decision. Sherwood compared the situation to Nabil Bentaleb at Tottenham, who chose Algeria over France, advising players to "go with your heart." Sherwood praised Grealish's confidence and ball skills, noting how defenders "kick lumps out of him" because of his dribbling ability. Grealish's father Kevin agreed with Sherwood's advice that Jack should concentrate on club football first. Grealish is expected to make his international choice at the end of the season and is reportedly split between the two countries.

The passage discusses landing fees for private jets at various airports worldwide. Private jet travel is a significant industry, with 2.5 million private flights in the US and 705,000 in Europe in 2013, worth $16.7 trillion and $15.8 trillion respectively.

The busiest times for private jets are during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, with flights costing tens of thousands of dollars. Popular routes include Los Angeles to Las Vegas (£2,890) and Milan to Rome ($5,880).

The passage lists the top 10 most expensive airports for landing fees (based on 767-400 aircraft):

1. Haneda Airport, Tokyo: £4,559
2. Narita International Airport, Tokyo: £3,728
3. Kansai International Airport, Osaka: £3,594
4. Toronto Pearson International: £3,461
5. Darwin International, Australia: £3,059
6. Bristol Airport, England: £2,929
7. Chūbu Centrair International, Nagoya: £2,863
8. Dublin Airport: £2,729
9. LaGuardia Airport, New York: £2,630
10. Salzburg Airport, Austria: £2,530

Japan dominates the list with three of the most expensive airports. The high fees at these airports reveal unexpected popular destinations for wealthy private jet travelers.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her two dogs - Cooper the labrador and Daisy, a smaller female pup - to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy took ladylike licks, Cooper devoured the entire cone in one bite. Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, says Cooper always eats quickly, so she ensures Daisy gets her share first. The video has been viewed over seven million times, receiving mixed reactions - some finding it cute while others criticized feeding dogs ice cream. Gallegos defended the practice, stating Cooper is healthy and athletic, and that her previous dog lived to 19 years old with weekly ice cream treats. The dogs also visit Starbucks for "pup-uccinos" (whipped cream in a cup), where Cooper again consumes everything quickly.

Gary Locke has been appointed as Kilmarnock's permanent manager on a three-year deal. The 41-year-old former Hearts boss initially joined Kilmarnock as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer, but took over as interim manager when Johnston left in early February. Since taking charge, Locke has had a successful run with only one loss in seven games. He will hold a press conference on Friday morning to discuss his appointment.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her 5-year-old autistic son Logan for wearing essential oils. The 32-year-old applies doTERRA oils (with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood) to his head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. 

Teachers complained the oils smelled and were distracting to other students, despite Logan using them all year without issue until a teacher's aide complained. Kemp received a letter from the school board stating the oils created a "problem" for staff and students. 

Kemp expressed frustration that she cannot use natural products while chemicals would be acceptable, and vowed to continue fighting the decision. However, Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend Logan, calling it a "health issue."

A beach-side apartment complex called the Sandpiper in Westhampton Beach, Hamptons, was destroyed by fire on Wednesday at 3 PM. The fire consumed 90 condos before the building collapsed. The cause of the fire is unknown, but it was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire teams responded but couldn't enter the building. The smoke was visible from three miles away. The complex, which operates as summer homes between May and November, was completely destroyed. The building manager lost everything in the fire. Fire officials are investigating claims that the fire may have started near a parked car.

The Queen, approaching her 89th birthday, was spotted riding her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, through Windsor Great Park in the spring sunshine. At 88 years old, she was accompanied by a groom on another Fell pony and wore a silk scarf instead of a helmet, as is her custom.

The Queen has never worn riding helmets, reportedly because of concerns about her hair. When asked by her racing trainer Ian Balding why she doesn't wear one, she replied: "I never have and you don't have to have your hair done like I do."

Her Majesty's love of horses began at age four when she received a Shetland pony named Peggy. Over the years, she has owned many horses, including Betsy in the 1950s and Surprise, whom she famously galloped at Ascot in 1961. Though she has reduced her riding in recent years due to a knee injury that also prevented her from riding at Trooping the Colour, she remains an enthusiastic equestrienne.

The Queen breeds Fell ponies at Hampton Court and Highland ponies at Balmoral. She takes keen interest in all her horses, some of which are now ridden by her grandchildren, including Prince Edward's children, Lady Louise and James, Viscount Severn.

Fell ponies, one of the oldest equine breeds, have roamed Cumbria since the Neolithic period. These docile, hardy ponies typically stand 13-14 hands high and come in black, grey, or bay colors. They have a rich history dating back to Iron Age tribes, Romans, and Vikings, and were extensively used as pack animals in British trade until the 18th century.

A 55-year-old Brisbane man, Leon Yeaman, died after being punched once in the head by his 28-year-old neighbor, Phillip Pama, during a noise dispute on Thursday night. The incident occurred on Muller Road in north Brisbane around 9 PM when Yeaman was allegedly making noise in his yard while Pama, a shift worker who starts at 3 AM, was trying to sleep. 

Pama, a married father of three with no history of violence, confronted Yeaman about the noise. According to Pama's lawyer, the situation escalated when Pama grabbed Yeaman's hand and struck out "blindly" while being pushed. Yeaman, described by neighbors as kind and generous but known for playing loud music when drunk, was pronounced dead at the scene around 11 PM despite paramedic efforts.

Pama has been charged with manslaughter and was granted conditional bail on Friday. His bail conditions include surrendering his passport, adhering to a 6 PM to 2 AM curfew, and reporting to police twice weekly. The case is scheduled to return to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old Russian music teacher, Yulia Simonova, was arrested after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former pupil, Damian Vanya, who had ended their relationship. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the hit after the teenager dumped her for a classmate. Police conducted a sting operation in Shatura, near Moscow, with an undercover officer posing as a hitman. Hidden camera footage captured Simonova detailing how she wanted the boy's arms and legs broken and his kidneys damaged so he would bleed out, before she would "finish him" herself. She had previously showered the pupil with gifts and money during their year-long relationship. After handing over expense money to the fake hitman, Simonova was arrested and charged with attempted murder, facing up to 15 years in prison.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho, 52, has revealed that he prays and talks to God daily but never about football. The father-of-two, who serves as an ambassador against hunger for the World Food Programme, says he keeps his professional and family life separate and never discusses football with his wife. While he doesn't attend church weekly, he goes when he feels the need and always attends when in Portugal. Despite his arrogant sideline persona, Mourinho claims he is a good family person and friend who tries to support others. He acknowledges making mistakes in his competitive professional life but emphasizes that a person is more than their career. Chelsea was top of the league at the time, and Mourinho had recently been fined £25,000 for claiming there was a campaign against the team.

Bob Barker, the 91-year-old TV legend who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, returned to the show for the first time in eight years on April 1. He handled the first segment of the show, hosting the classic "Lucky Seven" price-guessing game, before turning over hosting duties to current host Drew Carey. Despite his long absence, Barker appeared spry and performed smoothly without missing a beat.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

An off-duty Secret Service agent named Arthur Baldwin was arrested at 12:30 AM Friday in Washington D.C. for allegedly attempting to break into a house. He was charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property on the 3200 block of D Street SE in southeastern D.C. 

Baldwin worked with the Foreign Missions Branch of the Secret Service, which is attached to the State Department and handles U.S. diplomatic activities. Following his arrest, the agency revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave.

This incident comes just two days after another high-ranking Secret Service supervisor was put on leave for alleged misconduct. These events add to recent troubles for the agency, including a March 4 incident where two high-ranking officials allegedly drove into a secure White House area after drinking. The Department of Homeland Security's inspector general is investigating these misconduct allegations.

A freelance photographer named Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to photograph a hungry male lion at a safari park in Lahore. He left his car and crept to within 10 feet of the lion, lying on the ground armed only with his camera. After capturing a few frames, the camera's shutter sound alerted the lion to his presence. The lion aggressively jumped toward him, forcing Saeed to scramble back into his car, which had its door open. Though he laughed at the time, Saeed later reflected that he wouldn't attempt such a dangerous encounter again. His goal was to capture the character and status of the lion, which required this risky approach.

A woman between 25-45 years old was found unconscious on a Brooklyn street on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend. She was pronounced dead that evening after paramedics couldn't revive her. The woman had no identification, but police discovered a distinctive tattoo on her right leg featuring the name "Monique" on a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose. Nearly a month later, NYPD released images of the tattoo hoping to identify her. The cause of death is pending a medical examiner's report. Police are asking anyone with information to contact Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009 when they couldn't afford to buy property. Over a year and a half, they welded a steel frame and constructed a solar-powered, two-bedroom home made of wood and steel. The couple drove their completed truck home to a lot they purchased in Nelson, New Zealand, where they now live almost self-sufficiently with their cat. The home features aromatic cypress wood interiors, is powered mainly by solar panels (with their first power bill being just $25), uses gas for the stove and hot water, and gets water from a nearby spring. The entire project cost approximately $25,000, and the couple loves their unique home so much they plan to build another one someday.

Based on the passage, here is a concise summary of the core information:

Researchers found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class performed significantly better on early literacy tests compared to those who didn't use iPads or used them individually. In a study of 352 students at a midwestern suburban school district conducted over an academic year, children sharing iPads scored approximately 30 points higher than both non-iPad users and students with individual devices. 

The research was conducted by Courtney Blackwell from Northwestern University, who concluded that collaborative learning around the technology was the key factor in improved performance, rather than just collaboration itself. She suggests schools should reconsider how tablets are used, particularly in early grades, to maximize their effectiveness. The findings will be presented at the 65th annual International Communication Association conference in Puerto Rico.

This research comes amid skepticism from education leaders, including the general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, about using technology as a teaching aid in non-IT classes.

A piglet born without hind legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on just its two front legs. The pig, which belongs to farmer Ms. Duan, has mastered the art of balancing on its front trotters despite being born with its back legs missing. A heartwarming video shows the young animal taking unsteady steps with its snout to the ground while foraging for food, occasionally wobbling but always managing to regain balance. The piglet, nicknamed 'super pig,' happily mingles with its fully-formed siblings and has attracted many villagers who have come to see the curious animal. This is not the first two-legged animal to gain fame in China, as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo previously became a star attraction for walking on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, pit crew member Todd Phillips was injured in a pit lane incident. Phillips, who worked as a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was struck by Francesco Dracone's car when Dracone came in for tires and fuel on lap 25. Dracone lost control and spun while exiting his pit box, hitting Phillips' leg in the process. Phillips was treated at the infield care center where he received stitches for a leg laceration and was subsequently released. The race was affected by wet conditions, as rain had fallen for hours before the start, causing traction issues for many drivers. Dracone did not complete the race and finished in 23rd place.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 32-year-old Milton Vieira Severiano brutally murdered his 29-year-old dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), just four days after their marriage. CCTV footage captured him dragging her body into their apartment garden, smashing her head into concrete 11 times, punching her face 10 times, then shooting her in the face five times at point-blank range. 

Severiano confessed to police that he killed her because he was jealous of men looking at her. A neighbor reported hearing Severiano yelling at his wife, calling her "a slut" and saying she'd be "better off dead." The victim was a member of a dance group called Jaula das Gostozuedas. 

After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was caught by police after crashing during his escape. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his car. He now faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, 41-year-old journalist and author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed in an interview with Women's Weekly Australia that she came close to taking her own life due to mental illness. Her anxiety brought her to a point where she "couldn't see the existential point of continuing" and "couldn't see a way out."

Wilson attributed her crisis to multiple factors including mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family. She felt increasingly isolated, having not found a husband or had children while watching others move on with their lives. She described feeling "essentially very alone" and like she had "missed out on a guide book to life" when younger.

Wilson believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and calls anxiety the "new depression." She has recently "found some peace with it" and now accepts being an "anxious person." According to Beyond Blue statistics cited in the article, one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and while depression and anxiety are different conditions, one often leads to the other.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old Portland, Oregon woman who was seven months pregnant, was charged with second-degree assault in November 2014 after hitting her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. The incident occurred when Curtin came home to find the ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom. When the woman refused to leave, Curtin struck her in the head and arm with the crowbar.

Prosecutors dropped the charges on Monday, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Oregon law permits physical force against intruders who refuse to leave a resident's home. According to Curtin's defense attorney, the ex-girlfriend had harassed and threatened Curtin for two years and was attempting to drag the boyfriend back into heroin addiction.

Curtin gave birth in January and now lives with her parents. She is no longer with the boyfriend, who has not been involved with their child. Had she been convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of nearly six years.

A pit bull named Gemma from California was filmed being fed treats by her owner, who tried to trick her by including a piece of broccoli. When Gemma bit into the broccoli, she immediately showed disgust and spit it out on the floor. The passage notes that Gemma lives with two children and hopes they don't follow her example of rejecting vegetables. Besides eating, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website accidentally directed visitors to a pornographic website. The link was meant for the Young Entrepreneur Awards page, but after the awards were discontinued in 2011 and the registration was allowed to expire, a porn site took over the web address. When users clicked the link from HSBC's main website, they were shown explicit images instead of banking content. Upon discovering the error, HSBC removed the hyperlink and issued a public statement on April 20, denying any association with the third-party site and apologizing for the inconvenience. The bank confirmed that its website and internet banking services remained secure despite this embarrassing mistake.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 on Sunday morning after a fire broke out on the first floor of his Clinton home. He and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom because it was too hot to escape through the hallway. During the 11-minute call, Marcus remained calm, provided firefighters with specific directions to their location, and comforted his sister when she said "we're going to die." His mother, stepfather, and older brother were also in the home. Prince George's County firefighters rescued the siblings by breaking a window, with Lt. Kenny Ward giving his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both children were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries, while the three other family members escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Blue fluorescent algae created a spectacular light display along Australia's east coast, specifically at Jervis Bay in southern NSW. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured images of the phenomenon, describing it as a "beautiful supernatural scene" created by millions of light-emitting plankton. The glow is caused by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that typically blooms in spring and autumn. According to oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales, this carnivorous algae produces the luminous glow as a defense mechanism while preying on other algae called diatoms. A similar display occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, and experts confirm the phenomenon is natural and not a cause for concern, occurring due to natural causes 90% of the time.

New genetic tests can help breast cancer patients avoid chemotherapy by analyzing tumor cells to determine cancer aggressiveness and recurrence risk. The tests, including one called EndoPredict, screen cancer cells after surgery and can show if a patient has as low as a 5% chance of recurrence - similar to or better than chemotherapy outcomes. Currently, most breast cancer patients routinely receive chemotherapy after tumor removal, despite its severe side effects including hair loss, nausea, and extreme fatigue. These new tests, which cost about £2,500 privately, allow patients to make informed decisions about whether chemotherapy is necessary. Medical experts believe the tests could soon be available on the NHS, as the cost savings from avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy could offset the test expenses.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy over the past nine years, according to a Freedom of Information request. HMS Ocean had five pregnant sailors evacuated, while at least one woman was removed from HMS Illustrious. Eighteen other ships also had emergency evacuations. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict "no touching" rule exists at sea, suggesting women conceived before boarding or during leave. This data emerged nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was removed from her position following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Additionally, 99 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan between 2006-2013 after discovering they were pregnant, with another 102 evacuated from Iraq. Military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones, and those who discover pregnancies during operations are returned at the first opportunity.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's residence in Tokyo on Wednesday. The drone, measuring 50 centimeters wide with four propellers, was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material. Police believe the cesium was deliberately placed in the bottle, though the amount was not immediately harmful to humans.

The discovery occurred on the same day a Japanese court approved restarting two nuclear reactors at the Sendai plant, a move opposed by many Japanese citizens following the 2011 Fukushima disaster. Prime Minister Abe was not present, as he was attending a conference in Indonesia.

Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga expressed concerns about potential terrorism threats, particularly regarding future events like the Olympics and G7 summit. He noted that current Japanese law only restricts drone flights around airports, with no restrictions over most of Tokyo, including government buildings. The government pledged to review drone regulations and enhance counter-terrorism measures in response to this incident.

A security guard in Zhejiang province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother who suffers from Alzheimer's to work with him every day on his motorbike. Lu Xincai fears leaving her alone at home because she previously got lost while collecting firewood in the mountains. After his father passed away, with his wife working in another city and his son in school, he had no one else to care for her. Each morning at 5 am, he helps her onto his motorbike and ties a sash around both their waists for safety. The 4-kilometer journey takes an hour as he rides slowly. His employer, a bank, has provided a room for his mother, and he regularly checks on her during work. Lu views this as his duty, saying his mother devoted her life to caring for her children and now he must care for her in return.

A major study by the University of Washington's Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation found that heavy drinking among Americans increased 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, with women driving much of this increase. The study, published in the American Journal of Public Health, tracked drinking patterns at the county level for the first time.

Key findings include:
- In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers
- Women's binge drinking rates increased seven times faster than men's nationwide
- In Santa Clara County, California, women's binge drinking rose 36% compared to 23% for men
- Madison County, Idaho had the lowest binge drinking rate (6%), while Menominee, Wisconsin had the highest (36%)

The CDC defines heavy drinking as more than one drink per day for women and two for men, while binge drinking is 4+ drinks for women and 5+ for men on a single occasion. Experts attribute the increases to changing social norms making it more acceptable for women to drink like men, cheaper alcohol prices, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study analyzed data from 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older. Alcohol-related deaths totaled 88,600 in 2010, with excessive drinking costing over $220 billion annually.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting women and babies at risk. Currently, just over a quarter of women giving birth in England have caesareans, with rates more than doubling since the early 1990s. The World Health Organisation states the procedure should only be done when "medically necessary" and recommends rates between 10-15%, citing risks of infections, complications, disability, or death. A planned caesarean costs the NHS £2,369 compared to £1,665 for natural birth. This WHO guidance contradicts current NHS guidelines, which since 2011 allow caesareans for women with severe anxiety about childbirth (tokophobia) or other conditions like being over 40, having asthma, diabetes, or depression. Research shows one in ten caesareans cause infections.

A 44-year-old woman named Michelle Filkins from West Wareham was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into a Martha's Vineyard home, living there for at least a week, and selling the owners' belongings in a yard sale. The homeowner, Mark Conklin, discovered Filkins sitting in his living room of the $800,000 property on Court Street in Edgartown. When confronted, she claimed to own the house before fleeing in a gray Nissan pickup truck. Police found the home had been entered through a broken glass window that was covered with a blanket. Filkins was arrested hours later when she attempted to re-enter the home. She has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. A construction worker reported seeing her conducting what appeared to be a yard sale with items from the home. Missing items include furniture from Crate & Barrel and Ethan Allen, lamps, a Weber grill, kitchenware, linens, and a painting. Police are asking anyone who received items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

A woman named Bella Crooke from Melbourne lost her iPhone at a friend's birthday party on Saturday night. The phone was handed in to Albury police station on the NSW-Victoria border on Sunday morning. 

Finding the phone unlocked, police officers posted selfies and humorous photos on Bella's Facebook page to alert her. They photographed the phone in a holding "cell" and made puns about it being "charged" and a great "cell" phone, while advising her to add a password.

Bella called her phone after realizing it was missing and learned from a security guard that it was at the police station. When she arrived at 1 PM to collect it, she was unaware of the Facebook posts. Officers recognized her immediately from her profile and showed her the posts, which had already gained a humorous response from her friends who called the police "legends."

The police had also been responding to text messages from Bella's friends with similar humor. Bella found the situation hilarious and has since added a password to her phone, expressing gratitude to the police for returning it with such good humor.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed after getting caught in a fight between two adult male hippos at iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface when it strayed into the path of the fighting adults. The incident was witnessed by tour operator Stacey Farrell, who reported that the calf's mother had been trying to protect it by chasing away younger hippos for hours. When the mother briefly closed her eyes, a sub-adult hippo grabbed the calf. Despite the mother's attempts to rescue her baby by attacking the sub-adult's neck, this only caused the attacker to bite down harder and fling the calf into the air. The baby hippo died from its injuries hours after the attack, while its mother watched helplessly.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, one of Britain's most expensive areas, is on the market for £575,000 - significantly below neighboring property prices. However, the property has only three years remaining on its lease, making the effective cost £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, comparable to local rental rates.

The 1,990 sq/ft maisonette on Egerton Place is described as "bright and well proportioned" but requires modernization. It features three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and communal garden access. A second similar property is also available for £595,000.

If the lease is extended, the properties could be worth £6-7.5 million. However, extending the lease for 90 years would likely cost between £3.35-4.5 million. The next cheapest three-bedroom property in Knightsbridge costs £1.5 million with only a 28-year lease.

Estate agents report high interest from locals, developers, and end users, noting such short-lease properties rarely come to market in Knightsbridge. The buildings date from 1893 and have housed notable residents including Sir Henry Fielding Dickens, son of Charles Dickens.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

On Friday evening, Starbucks experienced a computer outage that affected registers at 8,000 stores (7,000 in the US and 1,000 in Canada). The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, prevented stores from processing credit card transactions and ringing up sales. As a result, many locations gave away free drinks and baked goods to customers. 

The outage began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast. While some stores remained open and accepted cash only, many locations closed early to avoid giving away free products. Excited customers took to Twitter to share news of the giveaway and post photos of their free beverages.

Starbucks announced late Friday night that the issue had been resolved and stores would open for "business as usual" on Saturday. The outage also affected the company's Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. This technical problem occurred just one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion in net revenues.

According to a Wales extremism and counter terrorism unit officer, terrorists are training and radicalizing Muslims in rural areas of west Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire. Detective Constable Gareth Jones told Ceredigion council that these individuals participate in "seemingly ordinary activities" while harboring "ulterior motives."

The passage details several historical incidents of extremist activity in Wales dating back to 1998, including:
- Hate preacher Abu Hamza allegedly sending 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons
- Two 7/7 bombers photographed white water rafting in Bala, north Wales in 2005
- Three Cardiff men arrested in 2010 as part of an al-Qaeda inspired plot
- Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studying Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder

DC Jones emphasized that terrorism issues are not limited to large cities and stressed the importance of community intelligence in combating these activities.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

An Omura's whale, a species feared to be extinct, was found washed up on a remote beach in Exmouth, Western Australia, after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This marks the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The 5.68-meter juvenile female was initially difficult to identify, requiring DNA profiling for confirmation. Environment Minister Albert Jacob called the discovery "highly significant" as the species was only first scientifically described in 2003 and little is known about it. Omura's whales are typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. They have distinctive features including a sleek body, 53 vertebrae, and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried and will be recovered in a few years for further scientific study and potential museum display.

A Texas businesswoman, Cheryl Rios, argued that Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president because female hormones might make her irrational and start unnecessary wars. The article counters this view by pointing out that male hormones have historically impaired male leaders' decision-making, citing examples of male politicians whose scandals were hormone-driven. 

The piece highlights the persistent gender bias women face in politics and the workplace, noting that despite women outnumbering men in college and the workforce, bias limits their potential. Evidence includes more men named John, Robert, William or James on corporate boards than total women board members.

The article argues that gender equality benefits everyone - companies with women leaders make more money, involved fathers raise happier children, and diverse teams produce better results. It concludes by noting the irony that Rios threatened to move to Canada if Clinton were elected, apparently unaware that Canada had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is auctioning off his collection of over 200 antiques for an estimated £100,000 as he downsizes his home. The collection includes a hand-painted 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt (estimated at £4,000-£6,000), medieval longbows, paintings, furniture, swords, rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and rare books dating back to the 17th century. 

Hardy, known for playing Siegfried Farnon in "All Creatures Great and Small" and portraying Winston Churchill multiple times, is a military historian and medieval longbow expert who studied under J.R.R. Tolkien at Oxford. The 238-lot auction will take place at Dominic Winter auctioneers in Gloucestershire on Saturday. Hardy expressed sadness at parting with his treasured collection but continues television work despite retiring from stage acting after a fall two years ago.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead at their shared Winter Garden, Florida home on Saturday. Police discovered the body after an out-of-state family member requested a well-being check, and investigators determined foul play was involved.

Shemansky came to police attention after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day. He is currently on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was previously involuntarily committed for attempted suicide.

According to neighbors and his estranged wife's attorney, Shemansky was going through a divorce, and his wife had filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years prior. His mother was reportedly helping him through the divorce and may have prevented him from attending the scheduled visit with his son. Neighbors believe divorce-related paperwork he received Friday may have triggered him.

Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication after allegedly asking for water at the trailer park office shortly after the murder. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not disclosed how Sandra Shemansky was killed. His estranged wife is reportedly preparing to protect herself in case he arrives at her home.

The passage reports that Eugene, United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The IAAF Council bypassed the usual bidding process, citing a "unique strategic opportunity to host the IAAF World Championships for the first time in the USA." Eugene had previously failed in its bid for the 2019 championships, which went to Doha, Qatar. IAAF President Lamine Diack explained the decision was based on unprecedented cooperation between public authorities, private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and enthusiastic public support. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan was also awarded without a bidding process. The passage concludes with a reference to Mo Farah winning gold in the men's 10,000 meters at the 2013 championships in Moscow.

A 25-year-old aspiring model named Leonie Granger has been jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger, a care assistant from Gillingham, Kent, targeted Hassan after seeing him with £50 notes at a London casino. She befriended him using her looks, and he showered her with gifts, cash, and restaurant trips.

On the night of the murder, after Hassan took Granger to Nobu restaurant and gave her £1,000 to gamble at Palm Beach casino, she went to his Islington flat but left the door unlocked for her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, 28, and accomplice Nicholas Chandler, 29. The two men tied up Hassan and kicked him to death while searching for his hidden casino winnings, leaving him with multiple broken bones drowning in his own blood.

The attackers stole £3,000, his TV and mobile phone. They were caught through Granger's phone records, which included footage of them throwing stolen £50 notes around. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years. Judge William Kennedy described the attack as "pitiless and wicked." Hassan was known to keep large cash winnings around his flat, sometimes storing thousands of pounds in his microwave.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Cesc Fabregas, Chelsea's 27-year-old midfielder, appears to be continuing his pattern of struggling in the second half of the season. He performed poorly in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland on Tuesday, receiving just a 4/10 rating from a Spanish newspaper. Despite a brilliant start to the season at Chelsea where he looked set to break the Premier League assists record, his form has significantly declined since Christmas.

The passage notes that Barcelona, his former club, had previously highlighted this trend when he left, stating his contributions "gradually decreased as each season drew to a close." This pattern seems to be repeating - after recording 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, he has managed just one in his last five games and only four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015.

Fabregas is now unlikely to break Thierry Henry's record of 20 assists in a Premier League season. However, with nine games remaining and Chelsea still needing wins to secure the title, manager Jose Mourinho will be hoping Fabregas can rediscover his form, especially against six upcoming opponents he has previously provided assists against this season.

West Ham are discussing a deal for 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United. Beckford impressed during a two-week trial with West Ham's academy and is considered one of the hottest prospects from the Caribbean. He has also received offers from Belgian clubs and has been linked with various European clubs. Additionally, West Ham announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, making them the cheapest in the Premier League as they prepare to move to the 54,000 capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped their investigation into an assault on Mike Lane, 40, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, just three months after the January 24 attack at Everleigh, near Amesbury. Lane was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, suffering concussion, broken teeth, facial swelling, and subsequent memory loss after being kicked in the head. 

Despite receiving video evidence of the incident, a dossier including names of saboteurs and car registration numbers, and capturing the main suspect's face on video, Wiltshire Police have shelved the inquiry citing insufficient evidence. The attack occurred while 30 riders were following an artificial scent rather than hunting a fox, with about 15 protesters spraying hounds with citronella before five approached and initiated the violent confrontation.

Lane condemned the police decision as "pathetic," expressing loss of trust in law enforcement. The Countryside Alliance is now campaigning to ban face coverings for saboteurs to help bring criminals to justice. Wiltshire Police confirmed the case is recorded as undetected but could be reopened if new evidence emerges.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American who became a prominent English-language propagandist for al Qaeda, was killed in January 2015 in a U.S. counterterrorism operation. He was not specifically targeted in the strike. Another American al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, was also killed in what was likely a separate operation, along with two hostages - American Warren Weinstein and Italian Giovanni Lo Porto.

Gadahn was born in 1978 in California to parents who changed their name from Pearlman. He converted to Islam in 1995 and left for Pakistan in 1998, joining al Qaeda and becoming known as "Azzam the American." He rose through the ranks to become the organization's chief English-language propagandist, appearing in numerous videos threatening attacks, criticizing U.S. presidents, and urging Muslims to conduct lone-wolf attacks in America.

In 2006, he was indicted for treason and material support to al Qaeda and was placed on the FBI's most wanted terrorists list. His videos included tearing up his U.S. passport, praising attacks like Fort Hood and Benghazi, and calling for overthrow of governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. He was married to an Afghan woman and had at least one child.

A five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo has become an internet sensation after a viral video showcased his exceptional basketball skills. The child, who has been playing since age two and a half, demonstrates remarkable abilities including scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously while maintaining eye contact with the camera. His skills have impressed thousands of netizens across basketball-mad China, with many expressing disbelief at his talent and some even feeling ashamed of their own abilities in comparison. The video highlights China's passion for child prodigies, with Mai potentially following in the footsteps of China's most famous basketball star, Yao Ming.

Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined supporters of media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, a 69-year-old former Open University information officer who was jailed in 1981 for 'corrupting public morals', attended a Hacked Off rally at the Houses of Parliament on February 25. The rally, chaired by comedian John Cleese, aimed to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, campaigns against the Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants MPs to create a statutory body to regulate the press as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. PIE, formed in 1974, had allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL) to lobby for lowering the age of sexual consent to ten and legalizing incest. O'Carroll served on the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee. A Hacked Off spokesman stated the meeting was open and free for all members of the public to attend.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a unique catwalk for Ten Pieces' presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The lifestyle brand, headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a monochrome collection of ten unisex pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Models walked through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall with the ocean as backdrop. The show took place on an unseasonably warm 28-degree Celsius day, with guests enjoying refreshments while watching the minimalist, androgynous designs. Regular lap swimmers were displaced for the day, having to exercise at the beach instead.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan, age 28, spent Friday at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom safari park in northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. During the family trip, Khan fed a rare white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced he will fight former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent despite pressure to fight British rival Kell Brook.

A Palestinian teenager named Mohammed Abu Khdeir, 16, who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, had his name added to an Israeli memorial wall at Mount Herzl that commemorates fallen soldiers and terrorism victims. His inclusion sparked controversy as his father objected, stating he refused to have his son's name listed among "soldiers of the occupation" and that no one asked his permission. Almagor, an organization representing terror victims in Israel, also opposed the inclusion, calling Abu Khdeir's death a "rogue attack" rather than an act of terrorism and threatening to demand removal of their own family members' names if his remained. Following these complaints, Israel's National Insurance Institute agreed to remove Abu Khdeir's name from both the memorial wall and its website. The memorial controversy occurred as Israel prepared for its Memorial Day, and as judicial proceedings against the three suspects in Abu Khdeir's killing were underway.

A young boy repeatedly tries to use his family cat as a pillow in their garden, as filmed by his father (YouTube user Lionel Hutz from California). The footage shows the boy chasing the cat and lying down on the cat's belly multiple times. Each time the boy rests his head on the cat, the feline gets up and moves to a new spot, with the boy following. After several attempts, the cat gives up and goes indoors. The two later reconcile, with the boy shown feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia features testimony from former drug dealers, including Robert Kushner, 32, who lost his varsity basketball coaching position at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying. Kushner testified that undercover officers on trial stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Though the 2007 charges were expunged, Kushner was arrested again in 2011 (receiving four years probation) and pleaded guilty to a 2008 DUI. The school, which hired him in 2010 after he passed a background check, was unaware of his drug-dealing history. Six former drug squad officers face a 26-count indictment including racketeering conspiracy, extortion, robbery, kidnapping and drug dealing. Defense lawyers claim the government's case relies on testimony from 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, injured six people and caused a large fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred Monday night at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak, with no reported toxic chemical spill. Five of the six injured were hurt by broken glass and hospitalized. Over 600 firefighters responded and brought the fire under control by Tuesday morning. This was the plant's second explosion, following one in July 2013 with no casualties. The plant was originally planned for the densely populated city of Xiamen but was relocated to Zhangzhou in 2007 after public protests over pollution concerns. PX plants have sparked protests across China in recent years despite demonstrations being illegal.

Jack Grealish, the Aston Villa teenager who made his first Premier League start against QPR in a 3-3 draw, refuses to pull up his socks despite referees telling him to do so. The Republic of Ireland under-21 international wears his socks low, just above his children's-sized shinpads, as a lifelong superstition. He insists he will continue this practice, noting he hasn't been kicked in the shins yet. Grealish was pleased to make his first league start, even though it came in a tough relegation battle, and hopes to earn more starts before the season ends after his manager showed faith in him.

Based on the passage, here is a concise summary:

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage" according to her grandmother Cissy Houston. While no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive - not responding to visitors or familiar voices, with eyes that don't follow people around the room. She has been in this neurological state for nearly three months and has a tracheostomy.

Despite Bobby Brown's emotional statement that his daughter is "awake" and "watching" him, family attorney Christopher Brown clarified that while her condition has improved and she's out of ICU, she is beginning a long rehabilitation process. Doctors indicate she will have a long life, but the quality of that life won't be known for years. Cissy Houston expressed sadness that her granddaughter could remain in this condition for a lifetime, saying they can only trust in God for a miracle.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup tie and is close to reaching the final. In the first match, Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets. In the second match, Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova came from behind to beat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3 after saving a match point in the second set. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki's powerful play and had 13 double faults, but Lisicki's 63 unforced errors proved decisive. Russia needs just one win from Sunday's three remaining matches to reach the final and pursue their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

New South Wales residents are being warned to prepare for another storm system this week, following devastating wild weather that hit the state last week. Meteorologists predict an east coast low could bring heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday, particularly affecting the northern parts of the state and the already hard-hit Hunter region.

The State Emergency Service (SES) is still working through over 4,000 jobs from approximately 24,000 requests received during last week's storms. The SES is particularly concerned about the Hunter region, which suffered severe flooding and high winds. They worry that additional rain on saturated ground will raise flood levels again and that wind could topple already uprooted trees.

While the upcoming weather system is expected to move more quickly than last week's three-day event and may be positioned further from the coast, the Bureau of Meteorology warns that areas already affected by flooding could see further rainfall. The SES has over 1,000 personnel in the field, including 200 from other states, working to complete as many jobs as possible before the next system arrives.

A 38-year-old model named Nina Moric, who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied reports that she attempted suicide over the weekend. She posted photos on Instagram showing bruising on her arms to her 40,000+ followers. Italian media had reported she tried to take her own life and was found by her mother in her Milan apartment.

Moric clarified that she was hospitalized Saturday night due to a domestic accident, explaining she fell and hit her head because of low blood pressure. Her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso had initially seemed to confirm the suicide attempt to media, but Moric stated he was in Naples at the time.

The Croatian-born model said she was "shocked" by the suicide claims and reassured fans she was recovering at home and only needed rest. Italian media noted she had previously attempted suicide in 2009. Moric was formerly married to paparazzi photographer Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities, and they have a son together born in 2002.

Based on the passage, here is a concise summary:

As Kate and William await their second child, a YouGov poll for the Sunday Times reveals British public preferences for baby names. For a girl, Diana (after William's late mother) is the top choice at 12%, followed by Alice and Charlotte at 9% each. For a boy, James leads at 13%, with Alexander as second choice. 

The poll of 2,200 people showed 25% hoping for a girl versus only 3% wanting a boy. Social media users echoed support for the name Diana, with many expressing they would be emotional if chosen. Additionally, 68% of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others. Among the wounded was Afghan lawmaker Humayoon Humayoon, who was participating in the protests. The protesters were on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor when the attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed responsibility.

Based on the passage, here is a concise summary:

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The 31-year-old Brazilian right-back has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed at a press conference that Alves rejected a three-year contract extension that was conditional on him playing in 60% of matches. She stated that negotiations are over and expressed frustration that Barcelona waited until April to address his contract renewal.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old striker currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has called on Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Since arriving at Boca, Osvaldo has been successful, scoring three goals in six games.
